dn23:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā kumārakassapo kosalesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi yena setabyā nāma kosalānaṃ nagaraṃ tadavasari.
dn23:1.2.eng: At one time Venerable Kassapa the Prince was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of five hundred mendicants when he arrived at a Kosalan citadel named Setavyā.
dn23:1.2.comm: Kumārakassapa was ordained at twenty (Kd 1:75.1.1). He features in the Vammikasutta (MN 23), and his verses are collected in the Theragāthā (Thag 2.41). He was declared the foremost of those with brilliant speech (AN 1.217), apparently on the basis of this discourse. | The Pāyāsisuta is the only major Buddhist text that has a Jain parallel, Paesi-kahāṇayaṁ, a similar dialogue between Paesi and Keśin in Setavyā.

dn23:1.3.pli: Tatra sudaṃ āyasmā kumārakassapo setabyāyaṃ viharati uttarena setabyaṃ siṃsapāvane.
dn23:1.3.eng: He stayed in the grove of Indian Rosewood to the north of Setavyā.

dn23:1.4.pli: Tena kho pana samayena pāyāsi rājañño setabyaṃ ajjhāvasati sattussadaṃ satiṇakaṭṭhodakaṃ sadhaññaṃ rājabhoggaṃ raññā pasenadinā kosalena dinnaṃ rājadāyaṃ brahmadeyyaṃ.
dn23:1.4.eng: Now at that time the chieftain Pāyāsi was living in Setavyā. It was a crown property given by King Pasenadi of Kosala, teeming with living creatures, full of hay, wood, water, and grain, a royal park endowed to a brahmin.
dn23:1.4.comm: Pāyāsi was a khattiya yet he receives a brahmadeyya. The sense of brahmadeyya as a donation to brahmins is well attested in inscriptions, so I think this is likely a mistake in the text, rather than evidence that the practice was not for brahmins only.

dn23:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena pāyāsissa rājaññassa evarūpaṃ pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ uppannaṃ hoti:
dn23:2.1.eng: Now at that time Pāyāsi had the following harmful misconception:

dn23:2.2.pli: “itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko”ti.
dn23:2.2.eng: “There is no afterlife. No beings are reborn spontaneously. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds.”
dn23:2.2.comm: This is wrong view per MN 117:5.1.

dn23:2.3.eng: The brahmins and householders of Setavyā heard,

dn23:2.4.pli: “samaṇo khalu bho kumārakassapo samaṇassa gotamassa sāvako kosalesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi setabyaṃ anuppatto setabyāyaṃ viharati uttarena setabyaṃ siṃsapāvane.
dn23:2.4.eng: “It seems the ascetic Kassapa the Prince—a disciple of the ascetic Gotama—is staying in the grove of Indian Rosewood to the north of Setavyā.

dn23:2.5.pli: Taṃ kho pana bhavantaṃ kumārakassapaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:

dn23:2.6.pli: ‘paṇḍito byatto medhāvī bahussuto cittakathī kalyāṇapaṭibhāno vuddho ceva arahā ca.
dn23:2.6.eng: ‘He is astute, competent, intelligent, learned, a brilliant speaker, eloquent, mature, a perfected one.’

dn23:2.7.pli: Sādhu kho pana tathārūpānaṃ arahataṃ dassanaṃ hotī’”ti.
dn23:2.7.eng: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”

dn23:2.8.pli: Atha kho setabyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā setabyāya nikkhamitvā saṅghasaṅghī gaṇībhūtā uttarenamukhā gacchanti yena siṃsapāvanaṃ.
dn23:2.8.eng: Then, exiting Setavyā, they formed into companies and headed north to the grove.

dn23:3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena pāyāsi rājañño uparipāsāde divāseyyaṃ upagato hoti.
dn23:3.1.eng: Now at that time the chieftain Pāyāsi had retired to the upper floor of his stilt longhouse for his midday nap.

dn23:3.2.pli: Addasā kho pāyāsi rājañño setabyake brāhmaṇagahapatike setabyāya nikkhamitvā saṅghasaṅghī gaṇībhūte uttarenamukhe gacchante yena siṃsapāvanaṃ,
dn23:3.2.eng: He saw the brahmins and householders heading north towards the grove,

dn23:3.4.pli: “kiṃ nu kho, bho khatte, setabyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā setabyāya nikkhamitvā saṅghasaṅghī gaṇībhūtā uttarenamukhā gacchanti yena siṃsapāvanan”ti?
dn23:3.4.eng: “My butler, why are the brahmins and householders heading north towards the grove?”

dn23:3.5.pli: “Atthi kho, bho, samaṇo kumārakassapo, samaṇassa gotamassa sāvako kosalesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi setabyaṃ anuppatto setabyāyaṃ viharati uttarena setabyaṃ siṃsapāvane.
dn23:3.5.eng: “The ascetic Kassapa the Prince—a disciple of the ascetic Gotama—is staying in the grove of Indian Rosewood to the north of Setavyā.

dn23:3.6.pli: Taṃ kho pana bhavantaṃ kumārakassapaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:

dn23:3.7.pli: ‘paṇḍito byatto medhāvī bahussuto cittakathī kalyāṇapaṭibhāno vuddho ceva arahā cā’ti.
dn23:3.7.eng: ‘He is astute, competent, intelligent, learned, a brilliant speaker, eloquent, mature, a perfected one.’

dn23:3.8.eng: They’re going to see that Kassapa the Prince.”

dn23:3.9.pli: “Tena hi, bho khatte, yena setabyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā setabyake brāhmaṇagahapatike evaṃ vadehi:
dn23:3.9.eng: “Well then, go to the brahmins and householders and say to them:

dn23:3.11.pli: āgamentu kira bhavanto, pāyāsipi rājañño samaṇaṃ kumārakassapaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissatī’ti.
dn23:3.11.eng: you to wait, as he will also go to see the ascetic Kassapa the Prince.’

dn23:3.12.pli: Purā samaṇo kumārakassapo setabyake brāhmaṇagahapatike bāle abyatte saññāpeti:
dn23:3.12.eng: Before Kassapa the Prince persuades those foolish and incompetent brahmins and householders that

dn23:3.13.pli: ‘itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’ti.
dn23:3.13.eng: there is an afterlife, there are beings reborn spontaneously, and there is a fruit or result of good and bad deeds—

dn23:3.14.pli: Natthi hi, bho khatte, paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko”ti.
dn23:3.14.eng: for none of these things are true!”

dn23:3.15.pli: “Evaṃ, bho”ti kho so khattā pāyāsissa rājaññassa paṭissutvā yena setabyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā setabyake brāhmaṇagahapatike etadavoca:
dn23:3.15.eng: “Yes, worthy sir,” replied the butler, and did as he was asked.

dn23:3.16.pli: “pāyāsi, bho, rājañño evamāha, āgamentu kira bhavanto, pāyāsipi rājañño samaṇaṃ kumārakassapaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissatī”ti.

dn23:4.1.pli: Atha kho pāyāsi rājañño setabyakehi brāhmaṇagahapatikehi parivuto yena siṃsapāvanaṃ yenāyasmā kumārakassapo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā kumārakassapena saddhiṃ sammodi, sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
dn23:4.1.eng: Then Pāyāsi escorted by the brahmins and householders, went up to Kassapa the Prince, and exchanged greetings with him. When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.

dn23:4.2.pli: Setabyakāpi kho brāhmaṇagahapatikā appekacce āyasmantaṃ kumārakassapaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu;
dn23:4.2.eng: Before sitting down to one side, some of the brahmins and householders of Setavyā bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward Kassapa the Prince, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent.

dn23:4.4.pli: sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.

dn23:4.5.pli: Appekacce yenāyasmā kumārakassapo tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.

dn23:5.1.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho pāyāsi rājañño āyasmantaṃ kumārakassapaṃ etadavoca:
dn23:5.1.eng: Seated to one side, the chieftain Pāyāsi said to Venerable Kassapa the Prince,

dn23:5.2.eng: “Worthy Kassapa, this is my doctrine and view:

dn23:5.3.pli: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’”ti.
dn23:5.3.eng: ‘There is no afterlife. No beings are reborn spontaneously. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds.’”

dn23:5.4.pli: “Nāhaṃ, rājañña, evaṃvādiṃ evaṃdiṭṭhiṃ addasaṃ vā assosiṃ vā.
dn23:5.4.eng: “Chieftain, may I never see or hear of anyone holding such a doctrine or view!
dn23:5.4.comm: This idiom recurs at AN 6.38:1.5 where, as here, it refers to a well-known view and cannot mean that they have never heard of it. There the text and commentary read māhaṁ, which with the aorist is prohibitive not negatory. It is an idiom expressing dislike.

dn23:5.5.eng: For how on earth can anyone say such a thing?

dn23:5.6.pli: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’ti?

dn23:5.7.0.eng: 2.1. The Simile of the Moon and Sun

dn23:5.8.pli: Tena hi, rājañña, taññevettha paṭipucchissāmi, yathā te khameyya, tathā naṃ byākareyyāsi.
dn23:5.8.eng: Well then, chieftain, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.

dn23:5.10.pli: ime candimasūriyā imasmiṃ vā loke parasmiṃ vā, devā vā te manussā vā”ti?
dn23:5.10.eng: Are the moon and sun in this world or the other world? Are they gods or humans?”

dn23:5.11.pli: “Ime, bho kassapa, candimasūriyā parasmiṃ loke, na imasmiṃ; devā te na manussā”ti.
dn23:5.11.eng: “They are in the other world, worthy Kassapa, and they are gods, not humans.”
dn23:5.11.comm: While the world “down here” is bogged down in its messy and ephemeral issues, the heavenly bodies proceed in their serene, glorious, stately indifference. Ignoring gravity, self-luminous, and apparently eternal, they operate according to what appears to be an entirely different set of rules, a “meta-physics”. What Newton did in physics the Buddha did in spirituality: show that the heavens, despite appearances, operate with the same set of conditioned rules as apply down here.

dn23:5.12.pli: “Imināpi kho te, rājañña, pariyāyena evaṃ hotu—
dn23:5.12.eng: “By this method it ought to be proven that
dn23:5.12.comm: Kassapa’s argument here doesn’t directly establish his conclusion. It is possible that gods exist on an entirely separate plane that has nothing to do with kamma and rebirth.

dn23:5.13.pli: itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko”ti.
dn23:5.13.eng: there is an afterlife, there are beings reborn spontaneously, and there is a fruit or result of good and bad deeds.”

dn23:6.1.pli: “Kiñcāpi bhavaṃ kassapo evamāha, atha kho evaṃ me ettha hoti:
dn23:6.1.eng: “Even though the worthy Kassapa says this, still I think that

dn23:6.2.pli: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’”ti.
dn23:6.2.eng: there is no afterlife, no beings are reborn spontaneously, and there’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds.”

dn23:6.3.pli: “Atthi pana, rājañña, pariyāyo, yena te pariyāyena evaṃ hoti:
dn23:6.3.eng: “Is there a method by which you can prove what you say?”

dn23:6.4.pli: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’”ti?

dn23:6.5.pli: “Atthi, bho kassapa, pariyāyo, yena me pariyāyena evaṃ hoti:

dn23:6.6.pli: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’”ti.

dn23:6.8.pli: “Idha me, bho kassapa, mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā pāṇātipātī adinnādāyī kāmesumicchācārī musāvādī pisuṇavācā pharusavācā samphappalāpī abhijjhālū byāpannacittā micchādiṭṭhī.
dn23:6.8.eng: “Well, I have friends and colleagues, relatives and kin who kill living creatures, steal, and commit sexual misconduct. They use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re covetous, malicious, with wrong view.

dn23:6.9.pli: Te aparena samayena ābādhikā honti dukkhitā bāḷhagilānā.
dn23:6.9.eng: Some time later they become sick, suffering, gravely ill.

dn23:6.11.pli: ‘na dānime imamhā ābādhā vuṭṭhahissantī’ti tyāhaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vadāmi:
dn23:6.11.eng: they will not recover from their illness, I go to them and say,

dn23:6.12.pli: ‘santi kho, bho, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
dn23:6.12.eng: ‘Sirs, there are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

dn23:6.13.pli: “ye te pāṇātipātī adinnādāyī kāmesumicchācārī musāvādī pisuṇavācā pharusavācā samphappalāpī abhijjhālū byāpannacittā micchādiṭṭhī, te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjantī”ti.
dn23:6.13.eng: “Those who kill living creatures, steal, and commit sexual misconduct; use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; and are covetous, malicious, and have wrong view—when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.”

dn23:6.14.pli: Bhavanto kho pāṇātipātī adinnādāyī kāmesumicchācārī musāvādī pisuṇavācā pharusavācā samphappalāpī abhijjhālū byāpannacittā micchādiṭṭhī.

dn23:6.15.pli: Sace tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ saccaṃ vacanaṃ, bhavanto kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjissanti.
dn23:6.15.eng: If what those ascetics and brahmins say is true, when your body breaks up, after death, you’ll be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

dn23:6.16.pli: Sace, bho, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjeyyātha, yena me āgantvā āroceyyātha:
dn23:6.16.eng: If that happens, sirs, come and tell me that

dn23:6.17.pli: “itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko”ti.
dn23:6.17.eng: there is an afterlife, there are beings reborn spontaneously, and there is a fruit or result of good and bad deeds.

dn23:6.18.pli: Bhavanto kho pana me saddhāyikā paccayikā, yaṃ bhavantehi diṭṭhaṃ, yathā sāmaṃ diṭṭhaṃ evametaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
dn23:6.18.eng: I trust you and believe you. Anything you see will be just as if I’ve seen it for myself.’
dn23:6.18.comm: This is still a major factor in shaping belief. People will reject the opinions of experts and believe people that they know.

dn23:6.19.pli: Te me ‘sādhū’ti paṭissutvā neva āgantvā ārocenti, na pana dūtaṃ pahiṇanti.
dn23:6.19.eng: They agree to this. But they don’t come back to tell me, nor do they send a messenger.

dn23:6.20.pli: Ayampi kho, bho kassapa, pariyāyo, yena me pariyāyena evaṃ hoti:
dn23:6.20.eng: This is the method by which I prove that

dn23:6.21.pli: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’”ti.
dn23:6.21.eng: there is no afterlife, no beings are reborn spontaneously, and there’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds.”
dn23:6.21.comm: Compare Jaiminīya Brāhmaņa 1.42, where Varuṇa asphyxiated his son Bhṛgu in order to send him on a journey to the “other world”, inducing a near-death experience. Bhṛgu saw men cutting other men to pieces and eating them, and other sights both horrifying and beautiful, all the while wondering if what he saw was real, before his breath was returned to him.

dn23:7.1.pli: “Tena hi, rājañña, taññevettha paṭipucchissāmi. Yathā te khameyya tathā naṃ byākareyyāsi.
dn23:7.1.eng: “Well then, chieftain, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.

dn23:7.3.pli: idha te purisā coraṃ āgucāriṃ gahetvā dasseyyuṃ:
dn23:7.3.eng: Suppose they were to arrest a bandit, a criminal and present him to you, saying,

dn23:7.4.eng: ‘Sir, this is a bandit, a criminal.

dn23:7.5.pli: imassa yaṃ icchasi, taṃ daṇḍaṃ paṇehī’ti.

dn23:7.7.pli: ‘tena hi, bho, imaṃ purisaṃ daḷhāya rajjuyā pacchābāhaṃ gāḷhabandhanaṃ bandhitvā khuramuṇḍaṃ karitvā kharassarena paṇavena rathikāya rathikaṃ siṅghāṭakena siṅghāṭakaṃ parinetvā dakkhiṇena dvārena nikkhamitvā dakkhiṇato nagarassa āghātane sīsaṃ chindathā’ti.
dn23:7.7.eng: ‘Well then, my men, tie this man’s arms tightly behind his back with a strong rope. Shave his head and march him from street to street and square to square to the beating of a harsh drum. Then take him out the south gate and there, at the place of execution to the south of the city, chop off his head.’

dn23:7.8.pli: Te ‘sādhū’ti paṭissutvā taṃ purisaṃ daḷhāya rajjuyā pacchābāhaṃ gāḷhabandhanaṃ bandhitvā khuramuṇḍaṃ karitvā kharassarena paṇavena rathikāya rathikaṃ siṅghāṭakena siṅghāṭakaṃ parinetvā dakkhiṇena dvārena nikkhamitvā dakkhiṇato nagarassa āghātane nisīdāpeyyuṃ.
dn23:7.8.eng: Saying, ‘Good,’ they’d do as they were told, sitting him down at the place of execution.

dn23:7.9.pli: Labheyya nu kho so coro coraghātesu:
dn23:7.9.eng: Could that bandit get the executioners to wait, saying,

dn23:7.10.pli: ‘āgamentu tāva bhavanto coraghātā, amukasmiṃ me gāme vā nigame vā mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā, yāvāhaṃ tesaṃ uddisitvā āgacchāmī’ti, udāhu vippalapantasseva coraghātā sīsaṃ chindeyyun”ti?
dn23:7.10.eng: ‘Please, good executioners! I have friends and colleagues, relatives and kin in such and such village or town. Wait until I’ve visited them, then I’ll come back’? Or would they just chop off his head as he prattled on?”
dn23:7.10.comm: Follow PTS reading uddassetvā, which at MN 82:11.9 has the sense “visit”.

dn23:7.11.pli: “Na hi so, bho kassapa, coro labheyya coraghātesu:

dn23:7.12.pli: ‘āgamentu tāva bhavanto coraghātā amukasmiṃ me gāme vā nigame vā mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā, yāvāhaṃ tesaṃ uddisitvā āgacchāmī’ti.

dn23:7.13.pli: Atha kho naṃ vippalapantasseva coraghātā sīsaṃ chindeyyun”ti.

dn23:7.14.pli: “So hi nāma, rājañña, coro manusso manussabhūtesu coraghātesu na labhissati:
dn23:7.14.eng: “So even a human bandit couldn’t get his human executioners to stay his execution.

dn23:7.15.pli: ‘āgamentu tāva bhavanto coraghātā, amukasmiṃ me gāme vā nigame vā mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā, yāvāhaṃ tesaṃ uddisitvā āgacchāmī’ti.

dn23:7.16.pli: Kiṃ pana te mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā pāṇātipātī adinnādāyī kāmesumicchācārī musāvādī pisuṇavācā pharusavācā samphappalāpī abhijjhālū byāpannacittā micchādiṭṭhī, te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannā labhissanti nirayapālesu:
dn23:7.16.eng: What then of your friends and colleagues, relatives and kin who are reborn in a lower realm after doing bad things? Could they get the wardens of hell to wait, saying,

dn23:7.17.pli: ‘āgamentu tāva bhavanto nirayapālā, yāva mayaṃ pāyāsissa rājaññassa gantvā ārocema:
dn23:7.17.eng: ‘Please, good wardens of hell! Wait until I’ve gone to the chieftain Pāyāsi to tell him that

dn23:7.18.pli: “itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko”’ti?
dn23:7.18.eng: there is an afterlife, there are beings reborn spontaneously, and there is a fruit or result of good and bad deeds’?

dn23:7.19.pli: Imināpi kho te, rājañña, pariyāyena evaṃ hotu:
dn23:7.19.eng: By this method, too, it ought to be proven that
dn23:7.19.comm: Kassapa, however, has not established the existence of an afterlife, he has merely refuted Pāyāsi’s argument. Per Occam’s razor, the burden of proof lies on the one who wishes to establish the existence of the afterlife, not on the one who denies it. His arguments, however, become more persuasive if they are understood as building on the initial agreement on the divinity of the sun and moon. He knows that Pāyāsi accepts some form of other world, even if he says otherwise, so the argument hinges on whether Pāyāsi’s methods are sufficient to disprove the kind of other world that Kassapa proposes, i.e. one driven by kamma.

dn23:7.20.pli: ‘itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’”ti.
dn23:7.20.eng: there is an afterlife, there are beings reborn spontaneously, and there is a fruit or result of good and bad deeds.”

dn23:8.1.pli: “Kiñcāpi bhavaṃ kassapo evamāha, atha kho evaṃ me ettha hoti:
dn23:8.1.eng: “Even though the worthy Kassapa says this, still I think that

dn23:8.2.pli: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’”ti.

dn23:8.3.pli: “Atthi pana, rājañña, pariyāyo yena te pariyāyena evaṃ hoti:
dn23:8.3.eng: “Is there a method by which you can prove what you say?”

dn23:8.4.pli: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’”ti?

dn23:8.5.pli: “Atthi, bho kassapa, pariyāyo, yena me pariyāyena evaṃ hoti:

dn23:8.6.pli: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’”ti.

dn23:8.8.pli: “Idha me, bho kassapa, mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā pāṇātipātā paṭiviratā adinnādānā paṭiviratā kāmesumicchācārā paṭiviratā musāvādā paṭiviratā pisuṇāya vācāya paṭiviratā pharusāya vācāya paṭiviratā samphappalāpā paṭiviratā anabhijjhālū abyāpannacittā sammādiṭṭhī.
dn23:8.8.eng: “Well, I have friends and colleagues, relatives and kin who refrain from killing living creatures, stealing, and committing sexual misconduct. They refrain from speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re content, kind-hearted, with right view.

dn23:8.9.pli: Te aparena samayena ābādhikā honti dukkhitā bāḷhagilānā.
dn23:8.9.eng: Some time later they become sick, suffering, gravely ill.

dn23:8.11.pli: ‘na dānime imamhā ābādhā vuṭṭhahissantī’ti tyāhaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vadāmi:
dn23:8.11.eng: they will not recover from their illness, I go to them and say,

dn23:8.12.pli: ‘santi kho, bho, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
dn23:8.12.eng: ‘Sirs, there are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

dn23:8.13.pli: “ye te pāṇātipātā paṭiviratā adinnādānā paṭiviratā kāmesumicchācārā paṭiviratā musāvādā paṭiviratā pisuṇāya vācāya paṭiviratā pharusāya vācāya paṭiviratā samphappalāpā paṭiviratā anabhijjhālū abyāpannacittā sammādiṭṭhī te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjantī”ti.
dn23:8.13.eng: “Those who refrain from killing living creatures, stealing, and committing sexual misconduct; who refrain from speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; and are content, kind-hearted, with right view—when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.”

dn23:8.14.pli: Bhavanto kho pāṇātipātā paṭiviratā adinnādānā paṭiviratā kāmesumicchācārā paṭiviratā musāvādā paṭiviratā pisuṇāya vācāya paṭiviratā pharusāya vācāya paṭiviratā samphappalāpā paṭiviratā anabhijjhālū abyāpannacittā sammādiṭṭhī.

dn23:8.15.pli: Sace tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ saccaṃ vacanaṃ, bhavanto kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjissanti.
dn23:8.15.eng: If what those ascetics and brahmins say is true, when your body breaks up, after death, you’ll be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

dn23:8.16.pli: Sace, bho, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjeyyātha, yena me āgantvā āroceyyātha:
dn23:8.16.eng: If that happens, sirs, come and tell me that

dn23:8.17.pli: “itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko”ti.

dn23:8.18.pli: Bhavanto kho pana me saddhāyikā paccayikā, yaṃ bhavantehi diṭṭhaṃ, yathā sāmaṃ diṭṭhaṃ evametaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
dn23:8.18.eng: I trust you and believe you. Anything you see will be just as if I’ve seen it for myself.’

dn23:8.19.pli: Te me ‘sādhū’ti paṭissutvā neva āgantvā ārocenti, na pana dūtaṃ pahiṇanti.
dn23:8.19.eng: They agree to this. But they don’t come back to tell me, nor do they send a messenger.

dn23:8.20.pli: Ayampi kho, bho kassapa, pariyāyo, yena me pariyāyena evaṃ hoti:
dn23:8.20.eng: This is the method by which I prove that

dn23:8.21.pli: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’”ti.

dn23:9.1.eng: “Well then, chieftain, I shall give you a simile.

dn23:9.2.pli: Upamāya m’idhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṃ ājānanti.
dn23:9.2.eng: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.

dn23:9.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, rājañña, puriso gūthakūpe sasīsakaṃ nimuggo assa.
dn23:9.3.eng: Suppose there were a man sunk over his head in a sewer.

dn23:9.4.eng: Then you were to order someone

dn23:9.5.pli: ‘tena hi, bho, taṃ purisaṃ tamhā gūthakūpā uddharathā’ti.
dn23:9.5.eng: to pull him out of the sewer,

dn23:9.6.pli: Te ‘sādhū’ti paṭissutvā taṃ purisaṃ tamhā gūthakūpā uddhareyyuṃ.
dn23:9.6.eng: and they’d agree to do so.

dn23:9.8.pli: ‘tena hi, bho, tassa purisassa kāyā veḷupesikāhi gūthaṃ sunimmajjitaṃ nimmajjathā’ti.
dn23:9.8.eng: carefully scrape the dung off that man’s body with bamboo scrapers,

dn23:9.9.pli: Te ‘sādhū’ti paṭissutvā tassa purisassa kāyā veḷupesikāhi gūthaṃ sunimmajjitaṃ nimmajjeyyuṃ.
dn23:9.9.eng: and they’d agree to do so.

dn23:9.11.pli: ‘tena hi, bho, tassa purisassa kāyaṃ paṇḍumattikāya tikkhattuṃ subbaṭṭitaṃ ubbaṭṭethā’ti.
dn23:9.11.eng: carefully scrub that man’s body down with pale clay three times,

dn23:9.12.pli: Te tassa purisassa kāyaṃ paṇḍumattikāya tikkhattuṃ subbaṭṭitaṃ ubbaṭṭeyyuṃ.

dn23:9.14.pli: ‘tena hi, bho, taṃ purisaṃ telena abbhañjitvā sukhumena cuṇṇena tikkhattuṃ suppadhotaṃ karothā’ti.
dn23:9.14.eng: smear that man’s body with oil, and carefully wash him down with fine paste three times,

dn23:9.15.pli: Te taṃ purisaṃ telena abbhañjitvā sukhumena cuṇṇena tikkhattuṃ suppadhotaṃ kareyyuṃ.

dn23:9.17.pli: ‘tena hi, bho, tassa purisassa kesamassuṃ kappethā’ti.
dn23:9.17.eng: dress that man’s hair and beard,

dn23:9.20.pli: ‘tena hi, bho, tassa purisassa mahagghañca mālaṃ mahagghañca vilepanaṃ mahagghāni ca vatthāni upaharathā’ti.
dn23:9.20.eng: provide that man with costly garlands, makeup, and clothes,

dn23:9.21.pli: Te tassa purisassa mahagghañca mālaṃ mahagghañca vilepanaṃ mahagghāni ca vatthāni upahareyyuṃ.

dn23:9.23.pli: ‘tena hi, bho, taṃ purisaṃ pāsādaṃ āropetvā pañcakāmaguṇāni upaṭṭhāpethā’ti.
dn23:9.23.eng: bring that man up to the stilt longhouse and set him up with the five kinds of sensual stimulation,

dn23:9.24.pli: Te taṃ purisaṃ pāsādaṃ āropetvā pañcakāmaguṇāni upaṭṭhāpeyyuṃ.

dn23:9.26.pli: api nu tassa purisassa sunhātassa suvilittassa sukappitakesamassussa āmukkamālābharaṇassa odātavatthavasanassa uparipāsādavaragatassa pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitassa samaṅgībhūtassa paricārayamānassa punadeva tasmiṃ gūthakūpe nimujjitukāmatā assā”ti?
dn23:9.26.eng: Now that man is nicely bathed and anointed, with hair and beard dressed, bedecked with garlands and bracelets, dressed in white, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation upstairs in the royal longhouse. Would he want to plunge back into that sewer again?”

dn23:9.29.pli: “Asuci, bho kassapa, gūthakūpo asuci ceva asucisaṅkhāto ca duggandho ca duggandhasaṅkhāto ca jeguccho ca jegucchasaṅkhāto ca paṭikūlo ca paṭikūlasaṅkhāto cā”ti.
dn23:9.29.eng: Because that sewer is filthy, stinking, disgusting, and repulsive, and it’s regarded as such.”

dn23:9.30.pli: “Evameva kho, rājañña, manussā devānaṃ asucī ceva asucisaṅkhātā ca, duggandhā ca duggandhasaṅkhātā ca, jegucchā ca jegucchasaṅkhātā ca, paṭikūlā ca paṭikūlasaṅkhātā ca.
dn23:9.30.eng: “In the same way, chieftain, to the gods, human beings are filthy, stinking, disgusting, and repulsive, and are regarded as such.

dn23:9.31.pli: Yojanasataṃ kho, rājañña, manussagandho deve ubbādhati.
dn23:9.31.eng: The smell of humans reaches the gods even a hundred leagues away.
dn23:9.31.comm: Follow PTS reading ubbāhati. Cf. AN 3.93:6.4 for the sense “transport”.

dn23:9.32.pli: Kiṃ pana te mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā pāṇātipātā paṭiviratā adinnādānā paṭiviratā kāmesumicchācārā paṭiviratā musāvādā paṭiviratā pisuṇāya vācāya paṭiviratā pharusāya vācāya paṭiviratā samphappalāpā paṭiviratā anabhijjhālū abyāpannacittā sammādiṭṭhī, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannā te āgantvā ārocessanti:
dn23:9.32.eng: What then of your friends and colleagues, relatives and kin who are reborn in a higher realm after doing good things? Will they come back to tell you that

dn23:9.33.pli: ‘itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’ti?

dn23:9.34.pli: Imināpi kho te, rājañña, pariyāyena evaṃ hotu:
dn23:9.34.eng: By this method, too, it ought to be proven that

dn23:9.35.pli: ‘itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’”ti.

dn23:11.0.eng: 2.4. The Simile of the gods of the thirty-three

dn23:11.1.pli: “Tena hi, rājañña, taññevettha paṭipucchissāmi; yathā te khameyya, tathā naṃ byākareyyāsi.
dn23:11.1.eng: “Well then, chieftain, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.

dn23:11.2.pli: Yaṃ kho pana, rājañña, mānussakaṃ vassasataṃ, devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ eso eko rattindivo, tāya rattiyā tiṃsarattiyo māso, tena māsena dvādasamāsiyo saṃvaccharo, tena saṃvaccharena dibbaṃ vassasahassaṃ devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ āyuppamāṇaṃ.
dn23:11.2.eng: A hundred human years are equivalent to one day and night for the gods of the thirty-three. Thirty such days make a month, and twelve months make a year. The gods of the thirty-three have a lifespan of a thousand such years.

dn23:11.3.pli: Ye te mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā pāṇātipātā paṭiviratā adinnādānā paṭiviratā kāmesumicchācārā paṭiviratā musāvādā paṭiviratā surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā paṭiviratā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannā devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ sahabyataṃ.
dn23:11.3.eng: Now, as to your friends who are reborn in the company of the gods of the thirty-three after doing good things.

dn23:11.5.pli: ‘yāva mayaṃ dve vā tīṇi vā rattindivā dibbehi pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitā samaṅgībhūtā paricārema, atha mayaṃ pāyāsissa rājaññassa gantvā āroceyyāma:
dn23:11.5.eng: ‘First I’ll amuse myself for two or three days, supplied and provided with the five kinds of heavenly sensual stimulation. Then I’ll go back to Pāyāsi and tell him that

dn23:11.6.pli: “itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko”ti.

dn23:11.7.eng: Would they come back to tell you that

dn23:11.8.pli: itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’”ti?

dn23:11.10.pli: Api hi mayaṃ, bho kassapa, ciraṃ kālaṅkatāpi bhaveyyāma.
dn23:11.10.eng: For I would be long dead by then.
dn23:11.10.comm: This recognizes the relativity of time.

dn23:11.11.eng: But worthy Kassapa, who has told you

dn23:11.12.pli: ‘atthi devā tāvatiṃsā’ti vā ‘evaṃdīghāyukā devā tāvatiṃsā’ti vā.
dn23:11.12.eng: that the gods of the thirty-three exist, or that they have such a long lifespan?

dn23:11.13.comm: Pāyāsi makes a good point; he only relies on sources that he knows he can trust.

dn23:11.14.pli: ‘atthi devā tāvatiṃsā’ti vā ‘evaṃdīghāyukā devā tāvatiṃsā’ti vā”ti.

dn23:11.16.pli: “Seyyathāpi, rājañña, jaccandho puriso na passeyya kaṇha—sukkāni rūpāni, na passeyya nīlakāni rūpāni, na passeyya pītakāni rūpāni, na passeyya lohitakāni rūpāni, na passeyya mañjiṭṭhakāni rūpāni, na passeyya samavisamaṃ, na passeyya tārakāni rūpāni, na passeyya candimasūriye.
dn23:11.16.eng: “Chieftain, suppose there was a person blind from birth. They couldn’t see sights that are dark or bright, or blue, yellow, red, or magenta. They couldn’t see even and uneven ground, or the stars, or the moon and sun.

dn23:11.18.pli: ‘natthi kaṇhasukkāni rūpāni, natthi kaṇhasukkānaṃ rūpānaṃ dassāvī.
dn23:11.18.eng: ‘There’s no such thing as dark and bright sights, and no-one who sees them.

dn23:11.19.pli: Natthi nīlakāni rūpāni, natthi nīlakānaṃ rūpānaṃ dassāvī.
dn23:11.19.eng: There’s no such thing as blue,

dn23:11.20.pli: Natthi pītakāni rūpāni, natthi pītakānaṃ rūpānaṃ dassāvī.

dn23:11.21.pli: Natthi lohitakāni rūpāni, natthi lohitakānaṃ rūpānaṃ dassāvī.

dn23:11.22.pli: Natthi mañjiṭṭhakāni rūpāni, natthi mañjiṭṭhakānaṃ rūpānaṃ dassāvī.

dn23:11.24.pli: Natthi tārakāni rūpāni, natthi tārakānaṃ rūpānaṃ dassāvī.

dn23:11.25.eng: moon and sun, and no-one who sees these things.

dn23:11.26.pli: Ahametaṃ na jānāmi, ahametaṃ na passāmi, tasmā taṃ natthī’ti.
dn23:11.26.eng: I don’t know it or see it, therefore it doesn’t exist.’

dn23:11.27.pli: Sammā nu kho so, rājañña, vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?

dn23:11.29.pli: Atthi kaṇhasukkāni rūpāni, atthi kaṇhasukkānaṃ rūpānaṃ dassāvī.
dn23:11.29.eng: There are such things as dark and bright sights, and one who sees them.

dn23:11.30.pli: Atthi nīlakāni rūpāni, atthi nīlakānaṃ rūpānaṃ dassāvī …pe…
dn23:11.30.eng: And those other things are real, too, as is the one who sees them.

dn23:11.32.pli: Atthi tārakāni rūpāni, atthi tārakānaṃ rūpānaṃ dassāvī.

dn23:11.33.eng: So it’s not right to say this:

dn23:11.34.pli: ‘Ahametaṃ na jānāmi, ahametaṃ na passāmi, tasmā taṃ natthī’ti.
dn23:11.34.eng: ‘I don’t know it or see it, therefore it doesn’t exist.’”

dn23:11.35.pli: Na hi so, bho kassapa, sammā vadamāno vadeyyā”ti.

dn23:11.36.pli: “Evameva kho tvaṃ, rājañña, jaccandhūpamo maññe paṭibhāsi yaṃ maṃ tvaṃ evaṃ vadesi.
dn23:11.36.eng: “In the same way, chieftain, when you tell me you don’t believe me you seem like the blind man in the simile.

dn23:11.38.pli: ‘atthi devā tāvatiṃsā’ti vā, ‘evaṃdīghāyukā devā tāvatiṃsā’ti vā?

dn23:11.40.pli: ‘atthi devā tāvatiṃsā’ti vā ‘evaṃdīghāyukā devā tāvatiṃsā’ti vā”ti.

dn23:11.41.pli: “Na kho, rājañña, evaṃ paro loko daṭṭhabbo, yathā tvaṃ maññasi iminā maṃsacakkhunā.
dn23:11.41.eng: You can’t see the other world the way you think, with the eye of the flesh.
dn23:11.41.comm: Kassapa establishes the empirical method by which these truths are known. Science extends knowledge by means of external instruments, while meditation extends the scope of consciousness. A non-scientist cannot understand how a scientist establishes their conclusions, and can only rely on trust in the scientific establishment. Likewise a non-meditator cannot understand the capacity of expanded consciousness.

dn23:11.42.pli: Ye kho te, rājañña, samaṇabrāhmaṇā araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevanti, te tattha appamattā ātāpino pahitattā viharantā dibbacakkhuṃ visodhenti.
dn23:11.42.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who live in the wilderness, frequenting remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest. Meditating diligent, keen, and resolute, they purify the heavenly eye, the power of clairvoyance.

dn23:11.43.pli: Te dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena imañceva lokaṃ passanti parañca satte ca opapātike.
dn23:11.43.eng: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see this world and the other world, and sentient beings who are spontaneously reborn.

dn23:11.44.pli: Evañca kho, rājañña, paro loko daṭṭhabbo;
dn23:11.44.eng: That’s how to see the other world,

dn23:11.45.pli: na tveva yathā tvaṃ maññasi iminā maṃsacakkhunā.
dn23:11.45.eng: not how you think, with the eye of the flesh.

dn23:11.46.pli: Imināpi kho te, rājañña, pariyāyena evaṃ hotu:
dn23:11.46.eng: By this method, too, it ought to be proven that

dn23:11.47.pli: ‘itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’”ti.

dn23:12.1.pli: “Kiñcāpi bhavaṃ kassapo evamāha, atha kho evaṃ me ettha hoti:
dn23:12.1.eng: “Even though the worthy Kassapa says this, still I think that

dn23:12.2.pli: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’”ti.

dn23:12.6.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, bho kassapa, passāmi samaṇabrāhmaṇe sīlavante kalyāṇadhamme jīvitukāme amaritukāme sukhakāme dukkhapaṭikūle.
dn23:12.6.eng: “Well, I see ascetics and brahmins who are ethical, of good character, who want to live and don’t want to die, who want to be happy and recoil from pain.

dn23:12.7.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bho kassapa, evaṃ hoti—

dn23:12.8.pli: sace kho ime bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā evaṃ jāneyyuṃ:
dn23:12.8.eng: ‘If those ascetics and brahmins knew that

dn23:12.9.eng: things were going to be better for them after death,

dn23:12.10.pli: Idānime bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā visaṃ vā khādeyyuṃ, satthaṃ vā āhareyyuṃ, ubbandhitvā vā kālaṃ kareyyuṃ, papāte vā papateyyuṃ.
dn23:12.10.eng: they’d drink poison, take their lives, hang themselves, or throw themselves off a cliff.

dn23:12.11.pli: Yasmā ca kho ime bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā na evaṃ jānanti:

dn23:12.12.pli: ‘ito no matānaṃ seyyo bhavissatī’ti, tasmā ime bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā jīvitukāmā amaritukāmā sukhakāmā dukkhapaṭikūlā attānaṃ na mārenti.
dn23:12.12.eng: things are going to be better for them after death. That’s why they are ethical, of good character, wanting to live and not wanting to die, wanting to be happy and recoiling from pain.’

dn23:12.13.pli: Ayampi kho, bho kassapa, pariyāyo, yena me pariyāyena evaṃ hoti:
dn23:12.13.eng: This is the method by which I prove that

dn23:12.14.pli: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’”ti.

dn23:13.0.eng: 2.6. The Simile of the Pregnant Woman

dn23:13.1.eng: “Well then, chieftain, I shall give you a simile.

dn23:13.2.pli: Upamāya m’idhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṃ ājānanti.
dn23:13.2.eng: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.

dn23:13.3.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, rājañña, aññatarassa brāhmaṇassa dve pajāpatiyo ahesuṃ.
dn23:13.3.eng: Once upon a time, a certain brahmin had two wives.

dn23:13.4.pli: Ekissā putto ahosi dasavassuddesiko vā dvādasavassuddesiko vā, ekā gabbhinī upavijaññā.
dn23:13.4.eng: One had a son ten or twelve years of age, while the other was pregnant and about to give birth.

dn23:13.6.pli: Atha kho so māṇavako mātusapattiṃ etadavoca:
dn23:13.6.eng: So the youth said to his mother’s co-wife,

dn23:13.7.pli: ‘yamidaṃ, bhoti, dhanaṃ vā dhaññaṃ vā rajataṃ vā jātarūpaṃ vā, sabbaṃ taṃ mayhaṃ;
dn23:13.7.eng: ‘Madam, all the money, grain, silver, and gold is mine,

dn23:13.9.eng: Transfer to me my father’s inheritance.’

dn23:13.10.pli: Evaṃ vutte, sā brāhmaṇī taṃ māṇavakaṃ etadavoca:

dn23:13.11.eng: ‘Wait, my dear, until I give birth.

dn23:13.12.pli: Sace kumārako bhavissati, tassapi ekadeso bhavissati;
dn23:13.12.eng: If it’s a boy, one portion shall be his.

dn23:13.13.pli: sace kumārikā bhavissati, sāpi te opabhoggā bhavissatī’ti.
dn23:13.13.eng: If it’s a girl, she will be your reward.’
dn23:13.13.comm: The commentary explains opabhoggā (“reward”) as pādaparicārikā (“wife”).

dn23:13.14.pli: Dutiyampi kho so māṇavako mātusapattiṃ etadavoca:

dn23:13.15.pli: ‘yamidaṃ, bhoti, dhanaṃ vā dhaññaṃ vā rajataṃ vā jātarūpaṃ vā, sabbaṃ taṃ mayhaṃ;

dn23:13.18.pli: Dutiyampi kho sā brāhmaṇī taṃ māṇavakaṃ etadavoca:

dn23:13.20.pli: Sace kumārako bhavissati, tassapi ekadeso bhavissati;

dn23:13.21.pli: sace kumārikā bhavissati sāpi te opabhoggā bhavissatī’ti.

dn23:13.22.pli: Tatiyampi kho so māṇavako mātusapattiṃ etadavoca:
dn23:13.22.eng: and a third time, the youth insisted that the entire inheritance must be his.

dn23:13.23.pli: ‘yamidaṃ, bhoti, dhanaṃ vā dhaññaṃ vā rajataṃ vā jātarūpaṃ vā, sabbaṃ taṃ mayhaṃ;

dn23:13.26.pli: Atha kho sā brāhmaṇī satthaṃ gahetvā ovarakaṃ pavisitvā udaraṃ opādesi:
dn23:13.26.eng: So the brahmin lady took a knife, went to her bedroom, and sliced open her belly, thinking,

dn23:13.27.pli: ‘yāva vijāyāmi yadi vā kumārako yadi vā kumārikā’ti.
dn23:13.27.eng: ‘Until I give birth—whether it’s a boy or a girl!’
dn23:13.27.comm: Prefer Mahāsaṅgīti reading yāva vijāyāmi over PTS yāva jānāmi (“until I know”); it echoes yāva vijāyāmi above. The phrase is not fully coherent, which is understandable given the circumstances.

dn23:13.28.pli: Sā attānañceva jīvitañca gabbhañca sāpateyyañca vināsesi.
dn23:13.28.eng: She destroyed her own life and that of the fetus, as well as any wealth.

dn23:13.29.pli: Yathā taṃ bālā abyattā anayabyasanaṃ āpannā ayoniso dāyajjaṃ gavesantī, evameva kho tvaṃ, rājañña, bālo abyatto anayabyasanaṃ āpajjissasi ayoniso paralokaṃ gavesanto;
dn23:13.29.eng: Being foolish and incompetent, she sought an inheritance irrationally and fell to ruin and disaster. In the same way, chieftain, being foolish and incompetent, you’re seeking the other world irrationally and will fall to ruin and disaster,
dn23:13.29.comm: “Irrationally” is ayoniso, literally “not sourcewise”. This passage gives a nice real world example of what it means: the means employed are unrelated to the end sought.

dn23:13.30.pli: seyyathāpi sā brāhmaṇī bālā abyattā anayabyasanaṃ āpannā ayoniso dāyajjaṃ gavesantī.

dn23:13.31.pli: Na kho, rājañña, samaṇabrāhmaṇā sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā apakkaṃ paripācenti;
dn23:13.31.eng: Good ascetics and brahmins don’t force what is unripe to ripen;

dn23:13.32.eng: rather, they wait for it to ripen.

dn23:13.33.pli: Paṇḍitānaṃ attho hi, rājañña, samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ sīlavantānaṃ kalyāṇadhammānaṃ jīvitena.
dn23:13.33.eng: For the life of clever ascetics and brahmins is beneficial.

dn23:13.34.pli: Yathā yathā kho, rājañña, samaṇabrāhmaṇā sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ tiṭṭhanti tathā tathā bahuṃ puññaṃ pasavanti, bahujanahitāya ca paṭipajjanti bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
dn23:13.34.eng: So long as they remain, good ascetics and brahmins produce much merit, and act for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.

dn23:13.35.pli: Imināpi kho te, rājañña, pariyāyena evaṃ hotu:
dn23:13.35.eng: By this method, too, it ought to be proven that

dn23:13.36.pli: ‘itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’”ti.

dn23:14.1.eng: “Even though the worthy Kassapa says this, still I think that

dn23:14.6.pli: “Idha me, bho kassapa, purisā coraṃ āgucāriṃ gahetvā dassenti:
dn23:14.6.eng: “Suppose they were to arrest a bandit, a criminal and present him to me, saying,

dn23:14.7.eng: ‘Sir, this is a bandit, a criminal.

dn23:14.8.pli: imassa yaṃ icchasi, taṃ daṇḍaṃ paṇehī’ti.

dn23:14.10.pli: ‘tena hi, bho, imaṃ purisaṃ jīvantaṃyeva kumbhiyā pakkhipitvā mukhaṃ pidahitvā allena cammena onandhitvā allāya mattikāya bahalāvalepanaṃ karitvā uddhanaṃ āropetvā aggiṃ dethā’ti.
dn23:14.10.eng: ‘Well then, sirs, place this man in a pot while he’s still alive. Close up the mouth, bind it up with damp leather, and seal it with a thick coat of damp clay. Then lift it up on a stove and light the fire.’
dn23:14.10.comm: Pāyāsi’s experiments were cruel, but no more so than many recorded in recent history.

dn23:14.11.pli: Te me ‘sādhū’ti paṭissutvā taṃ purisaṃ jīvantaṃyeva kumbhiyā pakkhipitvā mukhaṃ pidahitvā allena cammena onandhitvā allāya mattikāya bahalāvalepanaṃ karitvā uddhanaṃ āropetvā aggiṃ denti.
dn23:14.11.eng: They agree, and do what I ask.

dn23:14.12.pli: Yadā mayaṃ jānāma ‘kālaṅkato so puriso’ti, atha naṃ kumbhiṃ oropetvā ubbhinditvā mukhaṃ vivaritvā saṇikaṃ nillokema:
dn23:14.12.eng: When we know that that man has passed away, we lift down the pot and break it open, uncover the mouth, and slowly peek inside, thinking,

dn23:14.13.comm: We assume that a soul must be immaterial and invisible, but clearly this was not always the case at the time. From DN 1 we know that there was an almost inexhaustible variety of views about the self or soul.

dn23:14.14.eng: But we don’t see his soul escaping.

dn23:14.15.pli: Ayampi kho, bho kassapa, pariyāyo, yena me pariyāyena evaṃ hoti:
dn23:14.15.eng: This is how I prove that

dn23:14.16.pli: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’”ti.

dn23:15.1.pli: “Tena hi, rājañña, taññevettha paṭipucchissāmi, yathā te khameyya, tathā naṃ byākareyyāsi.
dn23:15.1.eng: “Well then, chieftain, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.

dn23:15.2.pli: Abhijānāsi no tvaṃ, rājañña, divā seyyaṃ upagato supinakaṃ passitā ārāmarāmaṇeyyakaṃ vanarāmaṇeyyakaṃ bhūmirāmaṇeyyakaṃ pokkharaṇīrāmaṇeyyakan”ti?
dn23:15.2.eng: Do you recall ever having a midday nap and seeing delightful parks, woods, meadows, and lotus ponds in a dream?”
dn23:15.2.comm: This echoes Upaniṣadic discussions of the nature of the dream state and its relation to death. See for example Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.1.18, which says one might become a brahmin or king in a dream.

dn23:15.3.pli: “Abhijānāmahaṃ, bho kassapa, divāseyyaṃ upagato supinakaṃ passitā ārāmarāmaṇeyyakaṃ vanarāmaṇeyyakaṃ bhūmirāmaṇeyyakaṃ pokkharaṇīrāmaṇeyyakan”ti.

dn23:15.4.pli: “Rakkhanti taṃ tamhi samaye khujjāpi vāmanakāpi velāsikāpi komārikāpī”ti?
dn23:15.4.eng: “At that time were you guarded by hunchbacks, dwarves, coquettes, and maidens?”

dn23:15.5.pli: “Evaṃ, bho kassapa, rakkhanti maṃ tamhi samaye khujjāpi vāmanakāpi velāsikāpi komārikāpī”ti.

dn23:15.6.pli: “Api nu tā tuyhaṃ jīvaṃ passanti pavisantaṃ vā nikkhamantaṃ vā”ti?
dn23:15.6.eng: “But did they see your soul entering or leaving?”
dn23:15.6.comm: Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3.19 describes the soul returning to the body like a tired hawk returning to the nest.

dn23:15.8.pli: “Tā hi nāma, rājañña, tuyhaṃ jīvantassa jīvantiyo jīvaṃ na passissanti pavisantaṃ vā nikkhamantaṃ vā.
dn23:15.8.eng: “So if they couldn’t even see your soul entering or leaving while you were still alive,

dn23:15.9.pli: Kiṃ pana tvaṃ kālaṅkatassa jīvaṃ passissasi pavisantaṃ vā nikkhamantaṃ vā.
dn23:15.9.eng: how could you see the soul of a dead man?

dn23:15.10.pli: Imināpi kho te, rājañña, pariyāyena evaṃ hotu:
dn23:15.10.eng: By this method, too, it ought to be proven that

dn23:15.11.pli: ‘itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’”ti.
dn23:15.11.eng: there is an afterlife, there are beings reborn spontaneously, and there is a fruit or result of good and bad deeds.”

dn23:16.1.pli: “Kiñcāpi bhavaṃ kassapo evamāha, atha kho evaṃ me ettha hoti:
dn23:16.1.eng: “Even though the worthy Kassapa says this, still I think that

dn23:16.2.pli: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’”ti.

dn23:16.6.pli: “Idha me, bho kassapa, purisā coraṃ āgucāriṃ gahetvā dassenti:
dn23:16.6.eng: “Suppose they were to arrest a bandit, a criminal and present him to me, saying,

dn23:16.7.eng: ‘Sir, this is a bandit, a criminal.

dn23:16.8.pli: imassa yaṃ icchasi, taṃ daṇḍaṃ paṇehī’ti.

dn23:16.10.pli: ‘tena hi, bho, imaṃ purisaṃ jīvantaṃyeva tulāya tuletvā jiyāya anassāsakaṃ māretvā punadeva tulāya tulethā’ti.
dn23:16.10.eng: ‘Well then, sirs, weigh this man with scales while he’s still alive. Then strangle him with a bowstring, and when he’s dead, weigh him again.’
dn23:16.10.comm: Aside from the cruelty, this echoes the dictum attributed to Galileo: “Measure what is measurable, and make measurable what is not so.” Given sufficient precision, this method could be effective in testing for the existence for a physical soul that has mass.

dn23:16.11.pli: Te me ‘sādhū’ti paṭissutvā taṃ purisaṃ jīvantaṃyeva tulāya tuletvā jiyāya anassāsakaṃ māretvā punadeva tulāya tulenti.
dn23:16.11.eng: They agree, and do what I ask.

dn23:16.12.pli: Yadā so jīvati, tadā lahutaro ca hoti mudutaro ca kammaññataro ca.
dn23:16.12.eng: So long as they are alive, they’re lighter, softer, more flexible.

dn23:16.13.pli: Yadā pana so kālaṅkato hoti tadā garutaro ca hoti patthinnataro ca akammaññataro ca.
dn23:16.13.eng: But when they die they become heavier, stiffer, less flexible.
dn23:16.13.comm: A dead body will, if anything, weigh less due to excretion and dehydration.

dn23:16.14.pli: Ayampi kho, bho kassapa, pariyāyo, yena me pariyāyena evaṃ hoti:
dn23:16.14.eng: This is how I prove that

dn23:17.0.eng: 2.8. The Simile of the Hot Iron Ball

dn23:17.1.eng: “Well then, chieftain, I shall give you a simile.

dn23:17.2.pli: Upamāya m’idhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṃ ājānanti.
dn23:17.2.eng: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.

dn23:17.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, rājañña, puriso divasaṃ santattaṃ ayoguḷaṃ ādittaṃ sampajjalitaṃ sajotibhūtaṃ tulāya tuleyya.
dn23:17.3.eng: Suppose a person was to heat an iron ball all day until it was burning, blazing, and glowing, and then they weigh it with scales.

dn23:17.4.pli: Tamenaṃ aparena samayena sītaṃ nibbutaṃ tulāya tuleyya.
dn23:17.4.eng: After some time, when it had cooled and become quenched, they’d weigh it again.

dn23:17.5.pli: Kadā nu kho so ayoguḷo lahutaro vā hoti mudutaro vā kammaññataro vā, yadā vā āditto sampajjalito sajotibhūto, yadā vā sīto nibbuto”ti?
dn23:17.5.eng: When would that iron ball be lighter, softer, and more workable—when it’s burning or when it’s cool?”
dn23:17.5.comm: The misconception that iron is lighter when heated is repeated elsewhere (eg. SN 51.22:4.1). In fact, assuming there are no chemical reactions, it will be very slightly heavier due to relativistic effects, yet less dense and hence more buoyant. These changes are too small to be detected by Pāyāsi’s methods, though.

dn23:17.6.pli: “Yadā so, bho kassapa, ayoguḷo tejosahagato ca hoti vāyosahagato ca āditto sampajjalito sajotibhūto, tadā lahutaro ca hoti mudutaro ca kammaññataro ca.
dn23:17.6.eng: “So long as the iron ball is full of heat and air—burning, blazing, and glowing—it’s lighter, softer, and more workable.

dn23:17.7.pli: Yadā pana so ayoguḷo neva tejosahagato hoti na vāyosahagato sīto nibbuto, tadā garutaro ca hoti patthinnataro ca akammaññataro cā”ti.
dn23:17.7.eng: But when it lacks heat and air—cooled and quenched—it’s heavier, stiffer, and less workable.”

dn23:17.8.pli: “Evameva kho, rājañña, yadāyaṃ kāyo āyusahagato ca hoti usmāsahagato ca viññāṇasahagato ca, tadā lahutaro ca hoti mudutaro ca kammaññataro ca.
dn23:17.8.eng: “In the same way, so long as this body is full of life and warmth and consciousness it’s lighter, softer, and more flexible.

dn23:17.9.pli: Yadā panāyaṃ kāyo neva āyusahagato hoti na usmāsahagato na viññāṇasahagato tadā garutaro ca hoti patthinnataro ca akammaññataro ca.
dn23:17.9.eng: But when it lacks life and warmth and consciousness it’s heavier, stiffer, and less flexible.

dn23:17.10.pli: Imināpi kho te, rājañña, pariyāyena evaṃ hotu:
dn23:17.10.eng: By this method, too, it ought to be proven that

dn23:17.11.pli: ‘itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’”ti.

dn23:18.12.pli: Yadā so āmato hoti, tyāhaṃ evaṃ vadāmi:
dn23:18.12.eng: When he’s nearly dead, I tell them to
dn23:18.12.comm: The commentary explains āmato as addhamato (“half-dead”).

dn23:18.13.pli: ‘tena hi, bho, imaṃ purisaṃ uttānaṃ nipātetha, appeva nāmassa jīvaṃ nikkhamantaṃ passeyyāmā’ti.
dn23:18.13.eng: lay him on his back in hope of seeing his soul escape.

dn23:18.15.eng: But we don’t see his soul escaping.

dn23:18.17.pli: ‘tena hi, bho, imaṃ purisaṃ avakujjaṃ nipātetha …

dn23:18.18.eng: to lay him on his side,

dn23:18.19.eng: to lay him on the other side;

dn23:18.26.pli: odhunātha sandhunātha niddhunātha, appeva nāmassa jīvaṃ nikkhamantaṃ passeyyāmā’ti.
dn23:18.26.eng: and to give him a good shaking in hope of seeing his soul escape.

dn23:18.27.pli: Te taṃ purisaṃ odhunanti sandhunanti niddhunanti.

dn23:18.28.eng: But we don’t see his soul escaping.

dn23:18.29.pli: Tassa tadeva cakkhu hoti te rūpā, tañcāyatanaṃ nappaṭisaṃvedeti.
dn23:18.29.eng: For him the eye itself is present, and so are those sights. Yet he does not experience that sense-field.
dn23:18.29.comm: At AN 9.37 this rather abrupt insertion more aptly describes a deep meditation.

dn23:18.30.pli: Tadeva sotaṃ hoti te saddā, tañcāyatanaṃ nappaṭisaṃvedeti.
dn23:18.30.eng: The ear itself is present, and so are those sounds. Yet he does not experience that sense-field.

dn23:18.31.pli: Tadeva ghānaṃ hoti te gandhā, tañcāyatanaṃ nappaṭisaṃvedeti.
dn23:18.31.eng: The nose itself is present, and so are those smells. Yet he does not experience that sense-field.

dn23:18.32.pli: Sāva jivhā hoti te rasā, tañcāyatanaṃ nappaṭisaṃvedeti.
dn23:18.32.eng: The tongue itself is present, and so are those tastes. Yet he does not experience that sense-field.

dn23:18.33.pli: Sveva kāyo hoti te phoṭṭhabbā, tañcāyatanaṃ nappaṭisaṃvedeti.
dn23:18.33.eng: The body itself is present, and so are those touches. Yet he does not experience that sense-field.

dn23:18.34.pli: Ayampi kho, bho kassapa, pariyāyo, yena me pariyāyena evaṃ hoti:
dn23:18.34.eng: This is how I prove that

dn23:18.35.pli: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’”ti.

dn23:19.0.eng: 2.9. The Simile of the Horn Blower

dn23:19.1.eng: “Well then, chieftain, I shall give you a simile.

dn23:19.2.pli: Upamāya m’idhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṃ ājānanti.
dn23:19.2.eng: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.

dn23:19.3.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, rājañña, aññataro saṅkhadhamo saṅkhaṃ ādāya paccantimaṃ janapadaṃ agamāsi.
dn23:19.3.eng: Once upon a time, a certain horn blower took his horn and traveled to a borderland,
dn23:19.3.comm: Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.4.8 employs the same metaphor in the search for the soul.

dn23:19.4.pli: So yena aññataro gāmo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā majjhe gāmassa ṭhito tikkhattuṃ saṅkhaṃ upalāpetvā saṅkhaṃ bhūmiyaṃ nikkhipitvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
dn23:19.4.eng: where he went to a certain village. Standing in the middle of the village, he sounded his horn three times, then placed it on the ground and sat down to one side.

dn23:19.5.pli: Atha kho, rājañña, tesaṃ paccantajanapadānaṃ manussānaṃ etadahosi:
dn23:19.5.eng: Then the people of the borderland thought,

dn23:19.6.pli: ‘ambho kassa nu kho eso saddo evaṃrajanīyo evaṅkamanīyo evaṃmadanīyo evambandhanīyo evaṃmucchanīyo’ti.
dn23:19.6.eng: ‘What is making this sound, so arousing, sensuous, intoxicating, infatuating, and captivating?’

dn23:19.7.eng: They gathered around the horn blower and said,

dn23:19.8.pli: ‘ambho, kassa nu kho eso saddo evaṃrajanīyo evaṅkamanīyo evaṃmadanīyo evambandhanīyo evaṃmucchanīyo’ti.
dn23:19.8.eng: ‘Worthy man, what is making this sound, so arousing, sensuous, intoxicating, infatuating, and captivating?’

dn23:19.9.pli: ‘Eso kho, bho, saṅkho nāma yasseso saddo evaṃrajanīyo evaṅkamanīyo evaṃmadanīyo evambandhanīyo evaṃmucchanīyo’ti.
dn23:19.9.eng: ‘The sound is made by this, which is called a horn.’

dn23:19.10.eng: They laid that horn on its back, saying,

dn23:19.12.eng: But still the horn made no sound.

dn23:19.13.pli: Te taṃ saṅkhaṃ avakujjaṃ nipātesuṃ, passena nipātesuṃ, dutiyena passena nipātesuṃ, uddhaṃ ṭhapesuṃ, omuddhakaṃ ṭhapesuṃ, pāṇinā ākoṭesuṃ, leḍḍunā ākoṭesuṃ, daṇḍena ākoṭesuṃ, satthena ākoṭesuṃ, odhuniṃsu sandhuniṃsu niddhuniṃsu:
dn23:19.13.eng: Then they lay the horn bent over, they lay it on its side, they lay it on its other side; they stood it upright, they stood it upside down; they struck it with fists, stones, rods, and swords; and they gave it a good shake, saying,

dn23:19.15.eng: But still the horn made no sound.

dn23:19.16.pli: Atha kho, rājañña, tassa saṅkhadhamassa etadahosi:

dn23:19.17.pli: ‘yāva bālā ime paccantajanapadā manussā, kathañhi nāma ayoniso saṅkhasaddaṃ gavesissantī’ti.
dn23:19.17.eng: ‘How foolish are these borderland folk! For how on earth can they seek the sound of a horn so irrationally?’

dn23:19.18.pli: Tesaṃ pekkhamānānaṃ saṅkhaṃ gahetvā tikkhattuṃ saṅkhaṃ upalāpetvā saṅkhaṃ ādāya pakkāmi.
dn23:19.18.eng: And as they looked on, he picked up the horn, sounded it three times, and took it away with him.

dn23:19.19.pli: Atha kho, rājañña, tesaṃ paccantajanapadānaṃ manussānaṃ etadahosi:
dn23:19.19.eng: Then the people of the borderland thought,

dn23:19.20.pli: ‘yadā kira, bho, ayaṃ saṅkho nāma purisasahagato ca hoti vāyāmasahagato ca vāyusahagato ca, tadāyaṃ saṅkho saddaṃ karoti, yadā panāyaṃ saṅkho neva purisasahagato hoti na vāyāmasahagato na vāyusahagato, nāyaṃ saṅkho saddaṃ karotī’ti.
dn23:19.20.eng: ‘So, it seems, when what is called a horn is accompanied by a person, effort, and wind, it makes a sound. But when these things are absent it makes no sound.’

dn23:19.21.pli: Evameva kho, rājañña, yadāyaṃ kāyo āyusahagato ca hoti usmāsahagato ca viññāṇasahagato ca, tadā abhikkamatipi paṭikkamatipi tiṭṭhatipi nisīdatipi seyyampi kappeti, cakkhunāpi rūpaṃ passati, sotenapi saddaṃ suṇāti, ghānenapi gandhaṃ ghāyati, jivhāyapi rasaṃ sāyati, kāyenapi phoṭṭhabbaṃ phusati, manasāpi dhammaṃ vijānāti.
dn23:19.21.eng: In the same way, so long as this body is full of life and warmth and consciousness it walks back and forth, stands, sits, and lies down. It sees sights with the eye, hears sounds with the ear, smells odors with the nose, tastes flavors with the tongue, feels touches with the body, and knows ideas with the mind.

dn23:19.22.pli: Yadā panāyaṃ kāyo neva āyusahagato hoti, na usmāsahagato, na viññāṇasahagato, tadā neva abhikkamati na paṭikkamati na tiṭṭhati na nisīdati na seyyaṃ kappeti, cakkhunāpi rūpaṃ na passati, sotenapi saddaṃ na suṇāti, ghānenapi gandhaṃ na ghāyati, jivhāyapi rasaṃ na sāyati, kāyenapi phoṭṭhabbaṃ na phusati, manasāpi dhammaṃ na vijānāti.
dn23:19.22.eng: But when it lacks life and warmth and consciousness it does none of these things.

dn23:19.23.pli: Imināpi kho te, rājañña, pariyāyena evaṃ hotu:
dn23:19.23.eng: By this method, too, it ought to be proven that

dn23:19.24.pli: ‘itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’”ti.

dn23:20.1.pli: “Kiñcāpi bhavaṃ kassapo evamāha, atha kho evaṃ me ettha hoti:
dn23:20.1.eng: “Even though the worthy Kassapa says this, still I think that

dn23:20.2.pli: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’”ti.

dn23:20.6.pli: “Idha me, bho kassapa, purisā coraṃ āgucāriṃ gahetvā dassenti:
dn23:20.6.eng: “Suppose they were to arrest a bandit, a criminal and present him to me, saying,

dn23:20.7.eng: ‘Sir, this is a bandit, a criminal.

dn23:20.8.pli: imassa yaṃ icchasi, taṃ daṇḍaṃ paṇehī’ti.

dn23:20.10.pli: ‘tena hi, bho, imassa purisassa chaviṃ chindatha, appeva nāmassa jīvaṃ passeyyāmā’ti.
dn23:20.10.eng: ‘Well then, sirs, cut open this man’s outer skin. Hopefully we might see his soul.’

dn23:20.11.eng: They cut open his outer skin,

dn23:20.14.pli: ‘tena hi, bho, imassa purisassa cammaṃ chindatha, maṃsaṃ chindatha, nhāruṃ chindatha, aṭṭhiṃ chindatha, aṭṭhimiñjaṃ chindatha, appeva nāmassa jīvaṃ passeyyāmā’ti.
dn23:20.14.eng: ‘Well then, sirs, cut open his inner skin, flesh, sinews, bones, or marrow. Hopefully we’ll see his soul.’

dn23:20.15.pli: Te tassa purisassa aṭṭhimiñjaṃ chindanti, nevassa mayaṃ jīvaṃ passeyyāma.
dn23:20.15.eng: They do so, but we see no soul.

dn23:20.16.pli: Ayampi kho, bho kassapa, pariyāyo, yena me pariyāyena evaṃ hoti:
dn23:20.16.eng: This is how I prove that

dn23:20.17.pli: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’”ti.

dn23:21.0.eng: 2.10. The Simile of the Fire-Worshiping Matted-Hair Ascetic

dn23:21.1.eng: “Well then, chieftain, I shall give you a simile.

dn23:21.2.pli: Upamāya m’idhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṃ ājānanti.
dn23:21.2.eng: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.

dn23:21.3.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, rājañña, aññataro aggiko jaṭilo araññāyatane paṇṇakuṭiyā sammati.
dn23:21.3.eng: Once upon a time, a certain fire-worshiping matted-hair ascetic settled in a leaf hut in a wilderness region.
dn23:21.3.comm: Such “matted-hair ascetics” are apparently the “forest hermits” (vānaprastha) whose lifestyle Kauṭilya describes as “celibacy, sleeping on the ground, wearing matted hair and antelope skin, offering daily fire sacrifice, bathing, venerating gods, ancestors, and guests, and eating forest produce” (Arthaśāstra 1.3.11, Olivelle’s translation).

dn23:21.4.pli: Atha kho, rājañña, aññataro janapade sattho vuṭṭhāsi.
dn23:21.4.eng: Then a caravan came out from a certain country.

dn23:21.5.pli: Atha kho so sattho tassa aggikassa jaṭilassa assamassa sāmantā ekarattiṃ vasitvā pakkāmi.
dn23:21.5.eng: It stayed for one night not far from that ascetic’s hermitage, and then moved on.

dn23:21.6.pli: Atha kho, rājañña, tassa aggikassa jaṭilassa etadahosi:

dn23:21.7.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ yena so satthavāso tenupasaṅkameyyaṃ, appeva nāmettha kiñci upakaraṇaṃ adhigaccheyyan’ti.
dn23:21.7.eng: ‘Why don’t I go to that caravan’s campsite? Hopefully I’ll find something useful there.’

dn23:21.8.pli: Atha kho so aggiko jaṭilo kālasseva vuṭṭhāya yena so satthavāso tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā addasa tasmiṃ satthavāse daharaṃ kumāraṃ mandaṃ uttānaseyyakaṃ chaḍḍitaṃ.
dn23:21.8.eng: So he went, and he saw a little baby boy abandoned there.

dn23:21.9.eng: When he saw this he thought,

dn23:21.10.pli: ‘na kho me taṃ patirūpaṃ yaṃ me pekkhamānassa manussabhūto kālaṅkareyya;
dn23:21.10.eng: ‘It’s not proper for me to look on while a human being dies.

dn23:21.11.pli: yannūnāhaṃ imaṃ dārakaṃ assamaṃ netvā āpādeyyaṃ poseyyaṃ vaḍḍheyyan’ti.
dn23:21.11.eng: Why don’t I bring this boy back to my hermitage, nurse him, provide for him, and raise him?’

dn23:21.12.pli: Atha kho so aggiko jaṭilo taṃ dārakaṃ assamaṃ netvā āpādesi posesi vaḍḍhesi.

dn23:21.13.pli: Yadā so dārako dasavassuddesiko vā hoti dvādasavassuddesiko vā, atha kho tassa aggikassa jaṭilassa janapade kañcideva karaṇīyaṃ uppajji.
dn23:21.13.eng: When the boy was ten or twelve years old, the ascetic had some business come up in the country.

dn23:21.14.pli: Atha kho so aggiko jaṭilo taṃ dārakaṃ etadavoca:
dn23:21.14.eng: So he said to the boy,

dn23:21.15.eng: ‘My dear, I wish to go to the country.

dn23:21.18.pli: Sace ca te aggi nibbāyeyya, ayaṃ vāsī imāni kaṭṭhāni idaṃ araṇisahitaṃ, aggiṃ nibbattetvā aggiṃ paricareyyāsī’ti.
dn23:21.18.eng: But if you should extinguish it, here is the hatchet, the firewood, and the bundle of drill-sticks. Light the fire and serve it.’

dn23:21.19.pli: Atha kho so aggiko jaṭilo taṃ dārakaṃ evaṃ anusāsitvā janapadaṃ agamāsi.
dn23:21.19.eng: And having instructed the boy, the ascetic went to the country.

dn23:21.20.eng: But the boy was so engrossed in his play, the fire went out.

dn23:21.22.eng: ‘My father told me to serve the sacred flame.

dn23:21.25.pli: Sace ca te aggi nibbāyeyya, ayaṃ vāsī imāni kaṭṭhāni idaṃ araṇisahitaṃ, aggiṃ nibbattetvā aggiṃ paricareyyāsī”ti.

dn23:21.26.eng: Why don’t I light it again and serve it?’

dn23:21.27.pli: Atha kho so dārako araṇisahitaṃ vāsiyā tacchi:
dn23:21.27.eng: So he chopped the bundle of drill-sticks with the hatchet, thinking,

dn23:21.29.eng: But he still got no fire.

dn23:21.30.pli: Araṇisahitaṃ dvidhā phālesi, tidhā phālesi, catudhā phālesi, pañcadhā phālesi, dasadhā phālesi, satadhā phālesi, sakalikaṃ sakalikaṃ akāsi, sakalikaṃ sakalikaṃ karitvā udukkhale koṭṭesi, udukkhale koṭṭetvā mahāvāte opuni:
dn23:21.30.eng: He split the bundle of drill-sticks into two, three, four, five, ten, or a hundred parts. He chopped them into splinters, pounded them in a mortar, and swept them away in a strong wind, thinking,

dn23:21.32.eng: But he still got no fire.

dn23:21.33.pli: Atha kho so aggiko jaṭilo janapade taṃ karaṇīyaṃ tīretvā yena sako assamo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṃ dārakaṃ etadavoca:
dn23:21.33.eng: Then the matted-hair ascetic, having concluded his business in the country, returned to his own hermitage, and said to the boy,

dn23:21.34.eng: ‘I trust, my dear, that the fire didn’t go out?’

dn23:21.35.eng: And the boy told him what had happened.

dn23:21.37.pli: “pitā kho maṃ evaṃ avaca aggiṃ, tāta, paricareyyāsi.

dn23:21.38.pli: Mā ca te, tāta, aggi nibbāyi.

dn23:21.39.pli: Sace ca te aggi nibbāyeyya, ayaṃ vāsī imāni kaṭṭhāni idaṃ araṇisahitaṃ, aggiṃ nibbattetvā aggiṃ paricareyyāsīti.

dn23:21.41.pli: Atha khvāhaṃ, tāta, araṇisahitaṃ vāsiyā tacchiṃ:

dn23:21.44.pli: Araṇisahitaṃ dvidhā phālesiṃ, tidhā phālesiṃ, catudhā phālesiṃ, pañcadhā phālesiṃ, dasadhā phālesiṃ, satadhā phālesiṃ, sakalikaṃ sakalikaṃ akāsiṃ, sakalikaṃ sakalikaṃ karitvā udukkhale koṭṭesiṃ, udukkhale koṭṭetvā mahāvāte opuniṃ:

dn23:21.47.pli: Atha kho tassa aggikassa jaṭilassa etadahosi:

dn23:21.48.pli: ‘yāva bālo ayaṃ dārako abyatto, kathañhi nāma ayoniso aggiṃ gavesissatī’ti.
dn23:21.48.eng: ‘How foolish is this boy, how incompetent! For how on earth can he seek a fire so irrationally?’

dn23:21.49.pli: Tassa pekkhamānassa araṇisahitaṃ gahetvā aggiṃ nibbattetvā taṃ dārakaṃ etadavoca:
dn23:21.49.eng: So while the boy looked on, he took a bundle of fire-sticks, lit the fire, and said,

dn23:21.50.eng: ‘Dear boy, this is how to light a fire.

dn23:21.51.pli: Na tveva yathā tvaṃ bālo abyatto ayoniso aggiṃ gavesī’ti.
dn23:21.51.eng: Not the foolish and incompetent way you sought it so irrationally.’

dn23:21.52.pli: Evameva kho tvaṃ, rājañña, bālo abyatto ayoniso paralokaṃ gavesissasi.
dn23:21.52.eng: In the same way, chieftain, being foolish and incompetent, you seek the other world irrationally.

dn23:21.53.pli: Paṭinissajjetaṃ, rājañña, pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ; paṭinissajjetaṃ, rājañña, pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ.
dn23:21.53.eng: Let go of this harmful misconception, chieftain, let go of it!

dn23:21.54.pli: Mā te ahosi dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti.
dn23:21.54.eng: Don’t create lasting harm and suffering for yourself!”

dn23:22.1.pli: “Kiñcāpi bhavaṃ kassapo evamāha, atha kho nevāhaṃ sakkomi idaṃ pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ paṭinissajjituṃ.
dn23:22.1.eng: “Even though the worthy Kassapa says this, still I’m not able to let go of that harmful misconception.

dn23:22.2.pli: Rājāpi maṃ pasenadi kosalo jānāti tirorājānopi:
dn23:22.2.eng: King Pasenadi of Kosala knows my views, and so do foreign kings.

dn23:22.4.pli: “itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko”’ti.

dn23:22.5.pli: Sacāhaṃ, bho kassapa, idaṃ pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ paṭinissajjissāmi, bhavissanti me vattāro:
dn23:22.5.eng: If I let go of this harmful misconception, people will say,

dn23:22.6.eng: ‘How foolish is the chieftain Pāyāsi, how incompetent, that he should hold on to a mistake!’

dn23:22.7.pli: Kopenapi naṃ harissāmi, makkhenapi naṃ harissāmi, palāsenapi naṃ harissāmī”ti.
dn23:22.7.eng: I shall carry on with this view out of anger, contempt, and spite!”
dn23:22.7.comm: Pāyāsi honestly acknowledges the role of social conformity and shame in shaping views.

dn23:23.0.eng: 2.11. The Simile of the Two Caravan Leaders

dn23:23.1.eng: “Well then, chieftain, I shall give you a simile.

dn23:23.2.pli: Upamāya m’idhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṃ ājānanti.
dn23:23.2.eng: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.

dn23:23.3.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, rājañña, mahāsakaṭasattho sakaṭasahassaṃ puratthimā janapadā pacchimaṃ janapadaṃ agamāsi.
dn23:23.3.eng: Once upon a time, a large caravan of a thousand wagons traveled from a country in the east to the west.
dn23:23.3.comm: Although this became the first story of the Jātaka collection (Ja 1), here it is not a Jātaka, as it is not framed as a past life of the Buddha.

dn23:23.4.pli: So yena yena gacchi, khippaṃyeva pariyādiyati tiṇakaṭṭhodakaṃ haritakapaṇṇaṃ.
dn23:23.4.eng: Wherever they went they quickly used up the grass, wood, water, and the green foliage.

dn23:23.5.pli: Tasmiṃ kho pana satthe dve satthavāhā ahesuṃ eko pañcannaṃ sakaṭasatānaṃ, eko pañcannaṃ sakaṭasatānaṃ.
dn23:23.5.eng: Now, that caravan had two leaders, each in charge of five hundred wagons.

dn23:23.7.eng: ‘This is a large caravan of a thousand wagons.

dn23:23.8.pli: te mayaṃ yena yena gacchāma, khippameva pariyādiyati tiṇakaṭṭhodakaṃ haritakapaṇṇaṃ.
dn23:23.8.eng: Wherever we go we quickly use up the grass, wood, water, and the green foliage.
dn23:23.8.comm: While the places are not specified, the journey from “east to west” across desolate lands suggests they may have been venturing from the rich plains of the Ganges west across the Thar Desert of Rajasthan.

dn23:23.9.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ imaṃ satthaṃ dvidhā vibhajeyyāma—
dn23:23.9.eng: Why don’t we split the caravan in two halves?’

dn23:23.10.pli: ekato pañca sakaṭasatāni ekato pañca sakaṭasatānī’ti.

dn23:23.11.pli: Te taṃ satthaṃ dvidhā vibhajiṃsu ekato pañca sakaṭasatāni, ekato pañca sakaṭasatāni.

dn23:23.12.pli: Eko satthavāho bahuṃ tiṇañca kaṭṭhañca udakañca āropetvā satthaṃ payāpesi.
dn23:23.12.eng: One caravan leader, having prepared much grass, wood, and water, started the caravan.

dn23:23.25.eng: So let’s discard the grass, wood, and water and restart the caravan with lightly-laden wagons.’

dn23:23.26.pli: ‘Evaṃ, bho’ti kho te satthikā tassa satthavāhassa paṭissutvā chaḍḍetvā purāṇāni tiṇāni kaṭṭhāni udakāni lahubhārehi sakaṭehi satthaṃ payāpesuṃ.

dn23:23.35.eng: And the men and beasts in that caravan were all devoured by that non-human spirit.

dn23:23.51.eng: But this person is neither our friend nor relative. How can we proceed out of trust in him?
dn23:23.51.comm: Again the criteria that only those who are known may be trusted.

dn23:23.52.pli: Na vo chaḍḍetabbāni purāṇāni tiṇāni kaṭṭhāni udakāni, yathābhatena bhaṇḍena satthaṃ payāpetha.

dn23:23.62.eng: And they saw the other caravan that had come to ruin.

dn23:23.63.pli: Ye ca tasmiṃ satthepi ahesuṃ manussā vā pasū vā, tesañca aṭṭhikāneva addasaṃsu tena yakkhena amanussena bhakkhitānaṃ.
dn23:23.63.eng: And they saw the bones of the men and beasts who had been devoured by that non-human spirit.

dn23:23.64.pli: Atha kho so satthavāho satthike āmantesi:
dn23:23.64.eng: So the caravan leader addressed his drivers,

dn23:23.65.pli: ‘ayaṃ kho, bho, sattho anayabyasanaṃ āpanno, yathā taṃ tena bālena satthavāhena pariṇāyakena.
dn23:23.65.eng: ‘This caravan came to ruin, as happens when guided by a foolish caravan leader.

dn23:23.66.pli: Tena hi, bho, yānamhākaṃ satthe appasārāni paṇiyāni, tāni chaḍḍetvā, yāni imasmiṃ satthe mahāsārāni paṇiyāni, tāni ādiyathā’ti.
dn23:23.66.eng: Well then, sirs, discard any of our merchandise that’s of little value, and take what’s valuable from this caravan.’

dn23:23.67.pli: ‘Evaṃ, bho’ti kho te satthikā tassa satthavāhassa paṭissutvā yāni sakasmiṃ satthe appasārāni paṇiyāni, tāni chaḍḍetvā yāni tasmiṃ satthe mahāsārāni paṇiyāni, tāni ādiyitvā sotthinā taṃ kantāraṃ nitthariṃsu, yathā taṃ paṇḍitena satthavāhena pariṇāyakena.
dn23:23.67.eng: ‘Yes, worthy sir’ replied the drivers, and that’s what they did. They crossed over the desert safely, as happens when guided by an astute caravan leader.

dn23:23.68.pli: Evameva kho tvaṃ, rājañña, bālo abyatto anayabyasanaṃ āpajjissasi ayoniso paralokaṃ gavesanto, seyyathāpi so purimo satthavāho.
dn23:23.68.eng: In the same way, chieftain, being foolish and incompetent, you will come to ruin seeking the other world irrationally, like the first caravan leader.

dn23:23.69.pli: Yepi tava sotabbaṃ saddhātabbaṃ maññissanti, tepi anayabyasanaṃ āpajjissanti, seyyathāpi te satthikā.
dn23:23.69.eng: And those who think you’re worth listening to and trusting will also come to ruin, like the drivers.

dn23:23.70.pli: Paṭinissajjetaṃ, rājañña, pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ; paṭinissajjetaṃ, rājañña, pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ.
dn23:23.70.eng: Let go of this harmful misconception, chieftain, let go of it!

dn23:23.71.pli: Mā te ahosi dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti.
dn23:23.71.eng: Don’t create lasting harm and suffering for yourself!”

dn23:24.1.pli: “Kiñcāpi bhavaṃ kassapo evamāha, atha kho nevāhaṃ sakkomi idaṃ pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ paṭinissajjituṃ.
dn23:24.1.eng: “Even though the worthy Kassapa says this, still I’m not able to let go of that harmful misconception.

dn23:24.2.pli: Rājāpi maṃ pasenadi kosalo jānāti tirorājānopi: ‘pāyāsi rājañño evaṃvādī evaṃdiṭṭhī:
dn23:24.2.eng: King Pasenadi of Kosala knows my views, and so do foreign kings.

dn23:24.4.pli: Sacāhaṃ, bho kassapa, idaṃ pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ paṭinissajjissāmi, bhavissanti me vattāro:

dn23:24.6.pli: Kopenapi naṃ harissāmi, makkhenapi naṃ harissāmi, palāsenapi naṃ harissāmī”ti.
dn23:24.6.eng: I shall carry on with this view out of anger, contempt, and spite!”

dn23:25.1.eng: “Well then, chieftain, I shall give you a simile.

dn23:25.2.pli: Upamāya m’idhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṃ ājānanti.
dn23:25.2.eng: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.

dn23:25.3.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, rājañña, aññataro sūkaraposako puriso sakamhā gāmā aññaṃ gāmaṃ agamāsi.
dn23:25.3.eng: Once upon a time, a certain swineherd went from his own village to another village.

dn23:25.4.eng: There he saw a large pile of dry dung abandoned.

dn23:25.6.pli: ‘ayaṃ kho pahūto sukkhagūtho chaḍḍito, mama ca sūkarabhattaṃ;
dn23:25.6.eng: ‘This pile of dry dung can serve as food for my pigs.

dn23:25.7.eng: Why don’t I carry it off?’

dn23:25.8.pli: So uttarāsaṅgaṃ pattharitvā pahūtaṃ sukkhagūthaṃ ākiritvā bhaṇḍikaṃ bandhitvā sīse ubbāhetvā agamāsi.
dn23:25.8.eng: So he spread out his upper robe, shoveled the dry dung onto it, tied it up into a parcel, lifted it on to his head, and went on his way.

dn23:25.9.eng: While on his way a large sudden storm poured down.

dn23:25.10.pli: So uggharantaṃ paggharantaṃ yāva agganakhā gūthena makkhito gūthabhāraṃ ādāya agamāsi.
dn23:25.10.eng: Smeared with leaking, oozing dung down to his fingernails, he kept on carrying the load of dung.

dn23:25.11.eng: When people saw him they said,

dn23:25.12.pli: ‘kacci no tvaṃ, bhaṇe, ummatto, kacci viceto, kathañhi nāma uggharantaṃ paggharantaṃ yāva agganakhā gūthena makkhito gūthabhāraṃ harissasī’ti.
dn23:25.12.eng: ‘Have you gone mad, sir? Have you lost your mind? For how on earth can you, smeared with leaking, oozing dung down to your fingernails, keep on carrying that load of dung?’

dn23:25.13.pli: ‘Tumhe khvettha, bhaṇe, ummattā, tumhe vicetā, tathā hi pana me sūkarabhattan’ti.
dn23:25.13.eng: ‘You’re the mad ones, sirs! You’re the ones who’ve lost your minds! For this will serve as food for my pigs.’

dn23:25.14.pli: Evameva kho tvaṃ, rājañña, gūthabhārikūpamo maññe paṭibhāsi.
dn23:25.14.eng: In the same way, chieftain, you seem like the dung carrier in the simile.

dn23:25.15.pli: Paṭinissajjetaṃ, rājañña, pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ; paṭinissajjetaṃ, rājañña, pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ.
dn23:25.15.eng: Let go of this harmful misconception, chieftain, let go of it!

dn23:25.16.pli: Mā te ahosi dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti.
dn23:25.16.eng: Don’t create lasting harm and suffering for yourself!”

dn23:27.3.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, rājañña, dve akkhadhuttā akkhehi dibbiṃsu.
dn23:27.3.eng: Once upon a time, two gamblers were playing with seed dice.

dn23:27.4.eng: One gambler, every time they took a bad hand, swallowed the losing seed.
dn23:27.4.comm: The ancient Indian game of dice involved casting vibhītaka seeds (also known as “bedda nuts”, from Terminalia bellirica) in a hollow, from which the players would take a handful. A number divisible by four was “perfect” (kaṭa), so the fifth seed meant a “losing” hand (kali; cf. apaṇṇaka in MN 60 and notes).

dn23:27.5.pli: Addasā kho dutiyo akkhadhutto taṃ akkhadhuttaṃ āgatāgataṃ kaliṃ gilantaṃ, disvā taṃ akkhadhuttaṃ etadavoca:
dn23:27.5.eng: The second gambler saw him, and said,

dn23:27.6.pli: ‘tvaṃ kho, samma, ekantikena jināsi, dehi me, samma, akkhe pajohissāmī’ti.
dn23:27.6.eng: ‘Well, my friend, you’ve won it all! Give me the seed dice, I will roll them.’
dn23:27.6.comm: Pajohissāmi is related to Sanskrit juhoti, usually used in the sense “to offer as libation”, a meaning accepted by the commentary here. More likely it simply means to “roll out” (like pouring a sacrifice) by analogy.

dn23:27.7.pli: ‘Evaṃ, sammā’ti kho so akkhadhutto tassa akkhadhuttassa akkhe pādāsi.
dn23:27.7.eng: ‘Yes, my friend,’ the gambler replied, and gave them.

dn23:27.8.pli: Atha kho so akkhadhutto akkhe visena paribhāvetvā taṃ akkhadhuttaṃ etadavoca:
dn23:27.8.eng: Then the gambler soaked the seed dice in poison and said to the other,

dn23:27.9.eng: ‘Come, my friend, let’s play seed dice.’

dn23:27.10.pli: ‘Evaṃ, sammā’ti kho so akkhadhutto tassa akkhadhuttassa paccassosi.
dn23:27.10.eng: ‘Yes, my friend,’ the other gambler replied.

dn23:27.11.pli: Dutiyampi kho te akkhadhuttā akkhehi dibbiṃsu.
dn23:27.11.eng: And for a second time the gamblers played with seed dice.

dn23:27.12.pli: Dutiyampi kho so akkhadhutto āgatāgataṃ kaliṃ gilati.
dn23:27.12.eng: And for the second time, every time they took a bad hand, that gambler swallowed the losing seed.

dn23:27.13.pli: Addasā kho dutiyo akkhadhutto taṃ akkhadhuttaṃ dutiyampi āgatāgataṃ kaliṃ gilantaṃ, disvā taṃ akkhadhuttaṃ etadavoca:
dn23:27.13.eng: The second gambler saw him, and said,

dn23:27.14.eng: ‘The man swallows the dice without realizing

dn23:27.15.eng: they’re smeared with most terrible venom.

dn23:27.17.eng: Soon you’ll know the bitter fruit!’

dn23:27.18.pli: Evameva kho tvaṃ, rājañña, akkhadhuttakūpamo maññe paṭibhāsi.
dn23:27.18.eng: In the same way, chieftain, you seem like the gambler in the simile.

dn23:27.19.eng: Let go of this harmful misconception, chieftain, let go of it!

dn23:27.20.eng: Don’t create lasting harm and suffering for yourself!”
