dn23:29.0.eng: 2.14. The Simile of the Man Who Carried Hemp

dn23:29.1.eng: “Well then, chieftain, I shall give you a simile.

dn23:29.2.pli: upamāya m’idhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṃ ājānanti.
dn23:29.2.eng: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.

dn23:29.3.eng: Once upon a time, the inhabitants of a certain country emigrated.

dn23:29.4.eng: Then one friend said to another,

dn23:29.5.pli: ‘āyāma, samma, yena so janapado tenupasaṅkamissāma, appeva nāmettha kiñci dhanaṃ adhigaccheyyāmā’ti.
dn23:29.5.eng: ‘Come, my friend, let’s go to that country. Hopefully we’ll get some riches there!’

dn23:29.7.pli: Te yena so janapado, yena aññataraṃ gāmapaṭṭaṃ tenupasaṅkamiṃsu, tattha addasaṃsu pahūtaṃ sāṇaṃ chaḍḍitaṃ, disvā sahāyako sahāyakaṃ āmantesi:
dn23:29.7.eng: They went to that country, and to a certain deserted village. There they saw a pile of abandoned sunn hemp. Seeing it, one friend said to the other,
dn23:29.7.comm: Gāmapaṭṭaṁ (variants -padaṁ, -paddhanaṁ, -patthaṁ, pajjaṁ) is explained by the commentary as an abandoned village site.

dn23:29.8.pli: ‘idaṃ kho, samma, pahūtaṃ sāṇaṃ chaḍḍitaṃ, tena hi, samma, tvañca sāṇabhāraṃ bandha, ahañca sāṇabhāraṃ bandhissāmi, ubho sāṇabhāraṃ ādāya gamissāmā’ti.
dn23:29.8.eng: ‘This is a pile of abandoned sunn hemp. Well then, my friend, you make up a load of hemp, and I’ll make one too. Let’s both take a load of hemp and go on.’

dn23:29.9.pli: ‘Evaṃ, sammā’ti kho sahāyako sahāyakassa paṭissutvā sāṇabhāraṃ bandhitvā te ubho sāṇabhāraṃ ādāya yena aññataraṃ gāmapaṭṭaṃ tenupasaṅkamiṃsu.
dn23:29.9.eng: ‘Yes, my friend,’ he said. Carrying their loads of hemp they went to another deserted village.

dn23:29.10.pli: Tattha addasaṃsu pahūtaṃ sāṇasuttaṃ chaḍḍitaṃ, disvā sahāyako sahāyakaṃ āmantesi:
dn23:29.10.eng: There they saw much sunn hemp thread abandoned. Seeing it, one friend said to the other,

dn23:29.11.pli: ‘yassa kho, samma, atthāya iccheyyāma sāṇaṃ, idaṃ pahūtaṃ sāṇasuttaṃ chaḍḍitaṃ.
dn23:29.11.eng: ‘This pile of abandoned sunn hemp thread is just what we wanted the hemp for!

dn23:29.12.pli: Tena hi, samma, tvañca sāṇabhāraṃ chaḍḍehi, ahañca sāṇabhāraṃ chaḍḍessāmi, ubho sāṇasuttabhāraṃ ādāya gamissāmā’ti.
dn23:29.12.eng: Well then, my friend, let’s abandon our loads of hemp, and both take a load of hemp thread and go on.’

dn23:29.13.pli: ‘Ayaṃ kho me, samma, sāṇabhāro dūrābhato ca susannaddho ca, alaṃ me, tvaṃ pajānāhī’ti.
dn23:29.13.eng: ‘I’ve already carried this load of hemp a long way, and it’s well tied up. It’s good enough for me, you understand.’

dn23:29.14.pli: Atha kho so sahāyako sāṇabhāraṃ chaḍḍetvā sāṇasuttabhāraṃ ādiyi.
dn23:29.14.eng: So one friend abandoned their load of hemp and picked up a load of hemp thread.

dn23:29.15.eng: They went to another deserted village.

dn23:29.16.pli: Tattha addasaṃsu pahūtā sāṇiyo chaḍḍitā, disvā sahāyako sahāyakaṃ āmantesi:
dn23:29.16.eng: There they saw much sunn hemp cloth abandoned. Seeing it, one friend said to the other,

dn23:29.17.pli: ‘yassa kho, samma, atthāya iccheyyāma sāṇaṃ vā sāṇasuttaṃ vā, imā pahūtā sāṇiyo chaḍḍitā.
dn23:29.17.eng: ‘This pile of abandoned sunn hemp cloth is just what we wanted the hemp and hemp thread for!

dn23:29.18.pli: Tena hi, samma, tvañca sāṇabhāraṃ chaḍḍehi, ahañca sāṇasuttabhāraṃ chaḍḍessāmi, ubho sāṇibhāraṃ ādāya gamissāmā’ti.
dn23:29.18.eng: Well then, my friend, let’s abandon our loads, and both take a load of hemp cloth and go on.’

dn23:29.19.pli: ‘Ayaṃ kho me, samma, sāṇabhāro dūrābhato ca susannaddho ca, alaṃ me, tvaṃ pajānāhī’ti.
dn23:29.19.eng: ‘I’ve already carried this load of hemp a long way, and it’s well tied up. It’s good enough for me, you understand.’

dn23:29.20.pli: Atha kho so sahāyako sāṇasuttabhāraṃ chaḍḍetvā sāṇibhāraṃ ādiyi.
dn23:29.20.eng: So one friend abandoned their load of hemp thread and picked up a load of hemp cloth.

dn23:29.21.eng: They went to another deserted village.

dn23:29.22.pli: Tattha addasaṃsu pahūtaṃ khomaṃ chaḍḍitaṃ, disvā …pe…
dn23:29.22.eng: There they saw a pile of flax, and by turn,

dn23:29.33.pli: pahūtaṃ suvaṇṇaṃ chaḍḍitaṃ, disvā sahāyako sahāyakaṃ āmantesi:
dn23:29.33.eng: and gold abandoned. Seeing it, one friend said to the other,

dn23:29.34.pli: ‘yassa kho, samma, atthāya iccheyyāma sāṇaṃ vā sāṇasuttaṃ vā sāṇiyo vā khomaṃ vā khomasuttaṃ vā khomadussaṃ vā kappāsaṃ vā kappāsikasuttaṃ vā kappāsikadussaṃ vā ayaṃ vā lohaṃ vā tipuṃ vā sīsaṃ vā sajjhaṃ vā, idaṃ pahūtaṃ suvaṇṇaṃ chaḍḍitaṃ.
dn23:29.34.eng: ‘This pile of gold is just what we wanted all those other things for!

dn23:29.35.pli: Tena hi, samma, tvañca sāṇabhāraṃ chaḍḍehi, ahañca sajjhabhāraṃ chaḍḍessāmi, ubho suvaṇṇabhāraṃ ādāya gamissāmā’ti.
dn23:29.35.eng: Well then, my friend, let’s abandon our loads, and both take a load of gold and go on.’

dn23:29.36.pli: ‘Ayaṃ kho me, samma, sāṇabhāro dūrābhato ca susannaddho ca, alaṃ me tvaṃ pajānāhī’ti.
dn23:29.36.eng: ‘I’ve already carried this load of hemp a long way, and it’s well tied up. It’s good enough for me, you understand.’

dn23:29.37.pli: Atha kho so sahāyako sajjhabhāraṃ chaḍḍetvā suvaṇṇabhāraṃ ādiyi.
dn23:29.37.eng: So one friend abandoned their load of silver and picked up a load of gold.

dn23:29.38.eng: Then they returned to their own village.

dn23:29.39.pli: Tattha yo so sahāyako sāṇabhāraṃ ādāya agamāsi, tassa neva mātāpitaro abhinandiṃsu, na puttadārā abhinandiṃsu, na mittāmaccā abhinandiṃsu, na ca tatonidānaṃ sukhaṃ somanassaṃ adhigacchi.
dn23:29.39.eng: When one friend returned with a load of sunn hemp, they didn’t please their parents, their partners and children, or their friends and colleagues. And they got no pleasure and happiness on that account.

dn23:29.40.pli: Yo pana so sahāyako suvaṇṇabhāraṃ ādāya agamāsi, tassa mātāpitaropi abhinandiṃsu, puttadārāpi abhinandiṃsu, mittāmaccāpi abhinandiṃsu, tatonidānañca sukhaṃ somanassaṃ adhigacchi.
dn23:29.40.eng: But when the other friend returned with a load of gold, they pleased their parents, their partners and children, and their friends and colleagues. And they got much pleasure and happiness on that account.

dn23:29.41.pli: Evameva kho tvaṃ, rājañña, sāṇabhārikūpamo maññe paṭibhāsi.
dn23:29.41.eng: In the same way, chieftain, you seem like the hemp-carrier in the simile.

dn23:29.42.pli: Paṭinissajjetaṃ, rājañña, pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ; paṭinissajjetaṃ, rājañña, pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ.
dn23:29.42.eng: Let go of this harmful misconception, chieftain, let go of it!

dn23:29.43.pli: Mā te ahosi dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti.
dn23:29.43.eng: Don’t create lasting harm and suffering for yourself!”

dn23:30.1.pli: “Purimeneva ahaṃ opammena bhoto kassapassa attamano abhiraddho.
dn23:30.1.eng: “I was delighted and satisfied with your very first simile, worthy Kassapa!
dn23:30.1.comm: Say what you will about Pāyāsi, he had character.

dn23:30.2.pli: Api cāhaṃ imāni vicitrāni pañhāpaṭibhānāni sotukāmo evāhaṃ bhavantaṃ kassapaṃ paccanīkaṃ kātabbaṃ amaññissaṃ.
dn23:30.2.eng: Nevertheless, I wanted to hear your various solutions to the problem, so I thought I’d oppose you in this way.

dn23:30.3.pli: Abhikkantaṃ, bho kassapa, abhikkantaṃ, bho kassapa.

dn23:30.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, bho kassapa, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhotā kassapena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
dn23:30.4.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, the worthy Kassapa has made the teaching clear in many ways.

dn23:30.5.pli: Esāhaṃ, bho kassapa, taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi, dhammañca, bhikkhusaṅghañca.
dn23:30.5.eng: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

dn23:30.6.pli: Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ kassapo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gataṃ.
dn23:30.6.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Kassapa remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.

dn23:30.7.pli: Icchāmi cāhaṃ, bho kassapa, mahāyaññaṃ yajituṃ, anusāsatu maṃ bhavaṃ kassapo, yaṃ mamassa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
dn23:30.7.eng: Worthy Kassapa, I wish to perform a great sacrifice. Please instruct me so it will be for my lasting welfare and happiness.”

dn23:31.1.pli: “Yathārūpe kho, rājañña, yaññe gāvo vā haññanti ajeḷakā vā haññanti, kukkuṭasūkarā vā haññanti, vividhā vā pāṇā saṅghātaṃ āpajjanti, paṭiggāhakā ca honti micchādiṭṭhī micchāsaṅkappā micchāvācā micchākammantā micchāājīvā micchāvāyāmā micchāsatī micchāsamādhī, evarūpo kho, rājañña, yañño na mahapphalo hoti na mahānisaṃso na mahājutiko na mahāvipphāro.
dn23:31.1.eng: “Chieftain, take the kind of sacrifice where cattle, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, and various kinds of creatures are slaughtered. And the recipients have wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong immersion. That kind of sacrifice is not very fruitful or beneficial or dazzling or bountiful.

dn23:31.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, rājañña, kassako bījanaṅgalaṃ ādāya vanaṃ paviseyya.
dn23:31.2.eng: Suppose a farmer was to enter a wood taking seed and plough.

dn23:31.3.pli: So tattha dukkhette dubbhūme avihatakhāṇukaṇṭake bījāni patiṭṭhāpeyya khaṇḍāni pūtīni vātātapahatāni asāradāni asukhasayitāni.
dn23:31.3.eng: And on that barren field, that barren ground, with uncleared stumps he sowed seeds that were broken, spoiled, weather-damaged, infertile, and ill kept.

dn23:31.4.pli: Devo ca na kālena kālaṃ sammādhāraṃ anuppaveccheyya.
dn23:31.4.eng: And the heavens don’t provide enough rain when needed.

dn23:31.5.pli: Api nu tāni bījāni vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjeyyuṃ, kassako vā vipulaṃ phalaṃ adhigaccheyyā”ti?
dn23:31.5.eng: Would those seeds grow, increase, and mature, and would the farmer get abundant fruit?”

dn23:31.7.pli: “Evameva kho, rājañña, yathārūpe yaññe gāvo vā haññanti, ajeḷakā vā haññanti, kukkuṭasūkarā vā haññanti, vividhā vā pāṇā saṅghātaṃ āpajjanti, paṭiggāhakā ca honti micchādiṭṭhī micchāsaṅkappā micchāvācā micchākammantā micchāājīvā micchāvāyāmā micchāsatī micchāsamādhī, evarūpo kho, rājañña, yañño na mahapphalo hoti na mahānisaṃso na mahājutiko na mahāvipphāro.
dn23:31.7.eng: “In the same way, chieftain, take the kind of sacrifice where cattle, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, and various kinds of creatures are slaughtered. And the recipients have wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong immersion. That kind of sacrifice is not very fruitful or beneficial or dazzling or bountiful.

dn23:31.8.pli: Yathārūpe ca kho, rājañña, yaññe neva gāvo haññanti, na ajeḷakā haññanti, na kukkuṭasūkarā haññanti, na vividhā vā pāṇā saṅghātaṃ āpajjanti, paṭiggāhakā ca honti sammādiṭṭhī sammāsaṅkappā sammāvācā sammākammantā sammāājīvā sammāvāyāmā sammāsatī sammāsamādhī, evarūpo kho, rājañña, yañño mahapphalo hoti mahānisaṃso mahājutiko mahāvipphāro.
dn23:31.8.eng: But take the kind of sacrifice where cattle, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, and various kinds of creatures are not slaughtered. And the recipients have right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion. That kind of sacrifice is very fruitful and beneficial and dazzling and bountiful.

dn23:31.9.pli: Seyyathāpi, rājañña, kassako bījanaṅgalaṃ ādāya vanaṃ paviseyya.
dn23:31.9.eng: Suppose a farmer was to enter a wood taking seed and plough.

dn23:31.10.pli: So tattha sukhette subhūme suvihatakhāṇukaṇṭake bījāni patiṭṭhapeyya akhaṇḍāni apūtīni avātātapahatāni sāradāni sukhasayitāni.
dn23:31.10.eng: And on that fertile field, that fertile ground, with well-cleared stumps he sowed seeds that were intact, unspoiled, not weather-damaged, fertile, and well kept.

dn23:31.11.pli: Devo ca kālena kālaṃ sammādhāraṃ anuppaveccheyya.
dn23:31.11.eng: And the heavens provide plenty of rain when needed.

dn23:31.12.pli: Api nu tāni bījāni vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjeyyuṃ, kassako vā vipulaṃ phalaṃ adhigaccheyyā”ti?
dn23:31.12.eng: Would those seeds grow, increase, and mature, and would the farmer get abundant fruit?”

dn23:31.14.pli: “Evameva kho, rājañña, yathārūpe yaññe neva gāvo haññanti, na ajeḷakā haññanti, na kukkuṭasūkarā haññanti, na vividhā vā pāṇā saṅghātaṃ āpajjanti, paṭiggāhakā ca honti sammādiṭṭhī sammāsaṅkappā sammāvācā sammākammantā sammāājīvā sammāvāyāmā sammāsatī sammāsamādhī, evarūpo kho, rājañña, yañño mahapphalo hoti mahānisaṃso mahājutiko mahāvipphāro”ti.
dn23:31.14.eng: “In the same way, chieftain, take the kind of sacrifice where cattle, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, and various kinds of creatures are not slaughtered. And the recipients have right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion. That kind of sacrifice is very fruitful and beneficial and dazzling and bountiful.”

dn23:32.1.pli: Atha kho pāyāsi rājañño dānaṃ paṭṭhapesi samaṇabrāhmaṇakapaṇaddhikavaṇibbakayācakānaṃ.
dn23:32.1.eng: Then the chieftain Pāyāsi set up an offering for ascetics and brahmins, for paupers, vagrants, supplicants, and beggars.

dn23:32.2.pli: Tasmiṃ kho pana dāne evarūpaṃ bhojanaṃ dīyati kaṇājakaṃ bilaṅgadutiyaṃ, dhorakāni ca vatthāni guḷavālakāni.
dn23:32.2.eng: At that offering such food as rough gruel with false black pepper was given, and rough clothes with knotted fringes.
dn23:32.2.comm: Bilaṅga is allowed with other medicinal fruits at Kd 6:6.1.4. It is Sanskrit viḍaṅga, identified as embelia ribes or “false black pepper”. | For guḷavālakāni, guḷa is “ball”, vāla is “tail”; compare macchavāḷaka (“fish-tailed”) at Kd 15:29.4.2.

dn23:32.3.pli: Tasmiṃ kho pana dāne uttaro nāma māṇavo vāvaṭo ahosi.
dn23:32.3.eng: Now, it was a student named Uttara who organized that offering.

dn23:32.4.eng: When the offering was over he referred to it like this,

dn23:32.5.pli: “imināhaṃ dānena pāyāsiṃ rājaññameva imasmiṃ loke samāgacchiṃ, mā parasmin”ti.
dn23:32.5.eng: “Through this offering may I be together with the chieftain Pāyāsi in this world, but not in the next.”

dn23:32.7.pli: “uttaro kira māṇavo dānaṃ datvā evaṃ anuddisati:

dn23:32.8.pli: ‘imināhaṃ dānena pāyāsiṃ rājaññameva imasmiṃ loke samāgacchiṃ, mā parasmin’”ti.

dn23:32.9.pli: Atha kho pāyāsi rājañño uttaraṃ māṇavaṃ āmantāpetvā etadavoca:
dn23:32.9.eng: so he summoned Uttara and said,

dn23:32.10.pli: “saccaṃ kira tvaṃ, tāta uttara, dānaṃ datvā evaṃ anuddisasi:
dn23:32.10.eng: “Is it really true, dear Uttara, that you referred to the offering in this way?”

dn23:32.11.pli: ‘imināhaṃ dānena pāyāsiṃ rājaññameva imasmiṃ loke samāgacchiṃ, mā parasmin’”ti?

dn23:32.13.pli: “Kissa pana tvaṃ, tāta uttara, dānaṃ datvā evaṃ anuddisasi:

dn23:32.14.pli: ‘imināhaṃ dānena pāyāsiṃ rājaññameva imasmiṃ loke samāgacchiṃ, mā parasmin’ti?

dn23:32.15.pli: Nanu mayaṃ, tāta uttara, puññatthikā dānasseva phalaṃ pāṭikaṅkhino”ti?
dn23:32.15.eng: Don’t we who seek merit expect some result from the offering?”

dn23:32.16.pli: “Bhoto kho dāne evarūpaṃ bhojanaṃ dīyati kaṇājakaṃ bilaṅgadutiyaṃ, yaṃ bhavaṃ pādāpi na iccheyya samphusituṃ, kuto bhuñjituṃ, dhorakāni ca vatthāni guḷavālakāni, yāni bhavaṃ pādāpi na iccheyya samphusituṃ, kuto paridahituṃ.
dn23:32.16.eng: “At your offering such food as rough gruel with false black pepper was given, which you wouldn’t even want to touch with your foot, much less eat. And also rough clothes with knotted fringes, which you also wouldn’t want to touch with your foot, much less wear.

dn23:32.17.pli: Bhavaṃ kho panamhākaṃ piyo manāpo, kathaṃ mayaṃ manāpaṃ amanāpena saṃyojemā”ti?
dn23:32.17.eng: Sir, you’re dear and beloved to me. But how can I reconcile one so dear with something so disagreeable?”

dn23:32.18.pli: “Tena hi tvaṃ, tāta uttara, yādisāhaṃ bhojanaṃ bhuñjāmi, tādisaṃ bhojanaṃ paṭṭhapehi.
dn23:32.18.eng: “Well then, dear Uttara, set up an offering with the same kind of food that I eat,

dn23:32.19.pli: Yādisāni cāhaṃ vatthāni paridahāmi, tādisāni ca vatthāni paṭṭhapehī”ti.
dn23:32.19.eng: and the same kind of clothes that I wear.”

dn23:32.20.pli: “Evaṃ, bho”ti kho uttaro māṇavo pāyāsissa rājaññassa paṭissutvā yādisaṃ bhojanaṃ pāyāsi rājañño bhuñjati, tādisaṃ bhojanaṃ paṭṭhapesi.
dn23:32.20.eng: “Yes, worthy sir,” replied Uttara, and did so.

dn23:32.21.pli: Yādisāni ca vatthāni pāyāsi rājañño paridahati, tādisāni ca vatthāni paṭṭhapesi.

dn23:32.22.pli: Atha kho pāyāsi rājañño asakkaccaṃ dānaṃ datvā asahatthā dānaṃ datvā acittīkataṃ dānaṃ datvā apaviddhaṃ dānaṃ datvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā cātumahārājikānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajji suññaṃ serīsakaṃ vimānaṃ.
dn23:32.22.eng: So the chieftain Pāyāsi gave gifts carelessly, thoughtlessly, not with his own hands, giving the dregs. When his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in company with the gods of the four great kings, in an empty palace of sirisa wood.

dn23:32.23.pli: Yo pana tassa dāne vāvaṭo ahosi uttaro nāma māṇavo. So sakkaccaṃ dānaṃ datvā sahatthā dānaṃ datvā cittīkataṃ dānaṃ datvā anapaviddhaṃ dānaṃ datvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajji devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ sahabyataṃ.
dn23:32.23.eng: But the student Uttara who organized the offering gave gifts carefully, thoughtfully, with his own hands, not giving the dregs. When his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in company with the gods of the thirty-three.

dn23:33.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā gavampati abhikkhaṇaṃ suññaṃ serīsakaṃ vimānaṃ divāvihāraṃ gacchati.
dn23:33.1.eng: Now at that time Venerable Gavampati would often go to that empty sirisa palace for the day’s meditation.
dn23:33.1.comm: Divāvihāra is the “day’s meditation”, while divāseyya is “siesta”.

dn23:33.2.pli: Atha kho pāyāsi devaputto yenāyasmā gavampati tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ gavampatiṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitaṃ kho pāyāsiṃ devaputtaṃ āyasmā gavampati etadavoca:
dn23:33.2.eng: Then the godling Pāyāsi went up to him, bowed, and stood to one side. Gavampati said to him,

dn23:33.6.pli: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’”ti?
dn23:33.6.eng: there is no afterlife, no beings are reborn spontaneously, and there’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds?”

dn23:33.7.eng: “It’s true, sir, I did have such a view.

dn23:33.8.pli: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko’ti.

dn23:33.9.pli: Api cāhaṃ ayyena kumārakassapena etasmā pāpakā diṭṭhigatā vivecito”ti.
dn23:33.9.eng: But Master Kassapa the Prince dissuaded me from that harmful misconception.”

dn23:33.10.pli: “Yo pana te, āvuso, dāne vāvaṭo ahosi uttaro nāma māṇavo, so kuhiṃ upapanno”ti?
dn23:33.10.eng: “But the student named Uttara who organized that offering for you—where has he been reborn?”

dn23:33.11.pli: “Yo me, bhante, dāne vāvaṭo ahosi uttaro nāma māṇavo, so sakkaccaṃ dānaṃ datvā sahatthā dānaṃ datvā cittīkataṃ dānaṃ datvā anapaviddhaṃ dānaṃ datvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapanno devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ sahabyataṃ.
dn23:33.11.eng: “Sir, Uttara gave gifts carefully, thoughtfully, with his own hands, not giving the dregs. When his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in company with the gods of the thirty-three.

dn23:33.12.pli: Ahaṃ pana, bhante, asakkaccaṃ dānaṃ datvā asahatthā dānaṃ datvā acittīkataṃ dānaṃ datvā apaviddhaṃ dānaṃ datvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā cātumahārājikānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapanno suññaṃ serīsakaṃ vimānaṃ.
dn23:33.12.eng: But I gave gifts carelessly, thoughtlessly, not with my own hands, giving the dregs. When my body broke up, after death, I was reborn in company with the gods of the four great kings, in an empty sirisa palace.

dn23:33.13.pli: Tena hi, bhante gavampati, manussalokaṃ gantvā evamārocehi:
dn23:33.13.eng: So, sir, when you’ve returned to the human realm, please announce this:

dn23:33.14.pli: ‘sakkaccaṃ dānaṃ detha, sahatthā dānaṃ detha, cittīkataṃ dānaṃ detha, anapaviddhaṃ dānaṃ detha.
dn23:33.14.eng: ‘Give gifts carefully, thoughtfully, with your own hands, not giving the dregs.

dn23:33.15.pli: Pāyāsi rājañño asakkaccaṃ dānaṃ datvā asahatthā dānaṃ datvā acittīkataṃ dānaṃ datvā apaviddhaṃ dānaṃ datvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā cātumahārājikānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapanno suññaṃ serīsakaṃ vimānaṃ.
dn23:33.15.eng: The chieftain Pāyāsi gave gifts carelessly, thoughtlessly, not with his own hands, giving the dregs. When his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in company with the gods of the four great kings, in an empty palace of sirisa.

dn23:33.16.pli: Yo pana tassa dāne vāvaṭo ahosi uttaro nāma māṇavo, so sakkaccaṃ dānaṃ datvā sahatthā dānaṃ datvā cittīkataṃ dānaṃ datvā anapaviddhaṃ dānaṃ datvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapanno devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ sahabyatan’”ti.
dn23:33.16.eng: But the student Uttara who organized the offering gave gifts carefully, thoughtfully, with his own hands, not giving the dregs. When his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in company with the gods of the Thirty-Three.’”

dn23:34.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā gavampati manussalokaṃ āgantvā evamārocesi:
dn23:34.1.eng: So when Venerable Gavampati returned to the human realm he made that announcement.

dn23:34.2.pli: “sakkaccaṃ dānaṃ detha, sahatthā dānaṃ detha, cittīkataṃ dānaṃ detha, anapaviddhaṃ dānaṃ detha.

dn23:34.3.pli: Pāyāsi rājañño asakkaccaṃ dānaṃ datvā asahatthā dānaṃ datvā acittīkataṃ dānaṃ datvā apaviddhaṃ dānaṃ datvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā cātumahārājikānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapanno suññaṃ serīsakaṃ vimānaṃ.

dn23:34.4.pli: Yo pana tassa dāne vāvaṭo ahosi uttaro nāma māṇavo, so sakkaccaṃ dānaṃ datvā sahatthā dānaṃ datvā cittīkataṃ dānaṃ datvā anapaviddhaṃ dānaṃ datvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapanno devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ sahabyatan”ti.
